text: Design: Crossed lines over the toytown tram: City transport could soon be back on the right track, says Jonathan Glancey
label: metaphor

text: MODERN trams, as most continental Europeans know, neither shake nor rattle, nor do they roll.
label: literal

text: Sleek, solidly built, gentle on the environment, they are often an ideal form of city transport.
label: metaphor

text: They also exert a fascination very much of their own as they slither round circuses and brush through old city gates, flashing arcs of lightning as they switch tracks on winter nights.
label: metaphor

text: Single-car, articulated or double-decker, trams are one of the most reliable and enduring forms of public transport invented.
label: metaphor

text: Eventually they will be replaced, but more than 60 years on they run with the rhythmic reliability of a Swiss watch.
label: metaphor

text: Last month it was announced that Britain will get its first new-wave trams in 1991.
label: metaphor

text: Destined to run in Manchester, they will relieve traffic congestion and help to reduce the levels of carbon monoxide in the city centre, outlying suburbs and satellite towns of Bury, Altrincham, Salford, Oldham and Rochdale.
label: metaphor

text: In Britain, with the main exception of Blackpool( not forgetting the single-deckers of the Isle of Man and Llandudno), trams had been largely relegated to the history books.
label: metaphor

text: Otherwise, the best place to see working trams has been the tram museum at Crich in Derbyshire or else in old British Transport Commission films and Ealing comedies.
label: metaphor

text: Trams disappeared from most British cities in the 1950s.
label: metaphor

text: London's venerable red and cream double-deckers rumbled along the Thames embankment for the last time in 1952.
label: metaphor

text: Somehow the image of the tall, thin, mournful double-deck tram with its wooden body, slatted wooden seats and growling electric motor has stuck in the British mind.
label: metaphor

text: Trams, it was believed until surprisingly recently, are old-fashioned.
label: metaphor

text: They had something to do with fish and chips wrapped in newspaper, men in hats, National Health specs, smog and powdered egg.
label: metaphor

text: They held up the bright new diesel buses and, even worse, blocked the progress of private motorists in bulbous Austins and lumpen Humbers in canyon-like city thoroughfares.
label: metaphor

text: They picked up power from a spider's web of unsightly overhead wires.
label: metaphor

text: They were inflexible in operation, draughty, and mobile reminders of TB epidemics with the enamelled â Do Not Spit signs screwed to their bulkheads.
label: metaphor

text: It plays a key role in keeping city streets on the move and is even the object of the best modern designers' desire.
label: metaphor

text: In Milan, for example, the commission to design the new generation of â Jumbo trams, which went into service in 1979, was one that leading Italian architects and designers fought over.
label: metaphor

text: After all, the Jumbo, a handsome and imposing articulated unit designed by architect, engineer and critic Klaus Giovanni Koenig, will be seen on the streets of Milan for the next half-century.
label: metaphor

text: Assuming the power station at the end of the line burns cleanly, the tram is virtually pollution free.
label: metaphor

text: Standing at traffic lights a Koenig-designed Jumbo is, save for the chatter inside, completely silent.
label: metaphor

text: The overhead wires are so slight that you have to look hard to see them.
label: metaphor

text: Powers of acceleration and braking are remarkable, the latter far greater than any car.
label: metaphor

text: But sadly, there is no indication that the GMA consortium which will design, operate and maintain the first of the new generation British trams in Manchester will share the looks of their Milanese counterparts.
label: metaphor

text: Artists' impressions show a tram that has more in common with the flat-faced, characterless light trains of the toy-like Docklands Light Railway.
label: metaphor

text: There is still time for GMA( GEC, Mowlem, Amec and Greater Manchester Buses) to consider employing an inspired architect or industrial designer.
label: metaphor

text: After all, Mancunians and visitors to the Manchester conurbation are going to have to look at these mechanical millipedes for well into the twenty-first century.
label: metaphor

text: Now that buses are no longer designed to enhance the streets they serve, Manchester has a chance to make a fresh start with its trams.
label: metaphor

text: Other British towns, Croydon and Southampton among them, are also considering modern tramways.
label: metaphor

text: These are all referred to as â supertram networks, the implication being that the new-generation tram is an altogether more dynamic form of transport than its pre-war predecessors.
label: metaphor

text: What it really means is that the new trams are a hybrid between street car and lightweight suburban train.
label: metaphor

text: Although they will slip through the city centre serving the essential parts â shopping malls, leisure centres, theme parks, amusement arcades and museums â the Manchester supertrams will also head out of town on a mix of reserved track and existing railway lines.
label: metaphor

text: The supertram is, in effect, a low-cost replacement for British Rail's ageing fleet of suburban diesel multiple-unit trains, those rasping diesels which change gear to the accompaniment of voluminous clouds of acrid black exhaust fumes and the blessing of train spotters.
label: metaphor

text: They will perform some of the same functions, but they will not be an exact replacement for traditional trams.
label: metaphor

text: And although the supertram concept will spread through major cities during the next decade, Blackpool will still be alone in its use of traditional double-deckers.
label: metaphor

text: IT WAS unfair of Auden to suggest, in his â Letter to Lord Byron, that a poet's â sense of other people's very hazy.
label: metaphor

text: But the vaporous presences that float through this slender and anaemic first novel by a notable poet would appear to support the claim.
label: metaphor

text: The book â which opens a projected sequence of novels that will cover the period from 1968 to the present day â aims to explore what the blurb describes as â the painful transition from youth to adulthood.
label: metaphor

text: This, of course, is a popular subject: it seems particularly attractive to the poet-turned-novelist because of the scope it offers for the tremulously sensitive probing of feelings.
label: metaphor

text: What Andrew Motion presents us with here is a static and humourless mood-piece filled with over-elaborate imagery.
label: metaphor

text: The hero, Francis Mayne, is suffering from the adolescent's emotional confusion and acute self-consciousness.
label: metaphor

text: He finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents.
label: metaphor

text: His mother, by contrast, is the most vividly realised character in the book: nervy, flirtatious and selfish, already on her third husband, she thinks primarily of her appearance, even when visiting her dying daughter, Francis's twin.
label: metaphor

text: The first half of the novel is dominated by the girl's death from leukaemia.
label: metaphor

text: There is a refreshing simplicity and tenderness in Motion's account of the way Francis nurses her, but she herself is too sketchily drawn for the episode to carry much weight.
label: metaphor

text: Meanwhile, at his public school, Francis is conducting a love-affair with an older pupil named Keith Ogilvie.
label: metaphor

text: He is finally rejected by the devious, arrogant Keith, who informs him that he is â obsolete because he does not â know how to make things happen.
label: metaphor

text: His response to this rejection is as flat as his reaction to the massive demonstration which Keith has earlier persuaded him to join against the Vietnam War.
label: metaphor

text: This violent event, described at length in hysterically colourful terms, is the only piece of history to be woven convincingly into the plot.
label: metaphor

text: Other broad hints as to the date are inserted with a comical lack of subtlety: â My God, darling, have you heard? exclaims Francis's mother one day as she greets him, â Czechoslovakia.
label: metaphor

text: It's been invaded.
label: literal

text: Motion will have to do better than this if he seriously intends his series of novels to capture the feel of a period.
label: metaphor

text: But the book's principal defect remains the vacuity of its protagonist.
label: literal

text: In his eagerness to depict the cloudy psychology of an adolescent, Motion has forgotten to give the boy a personality.
label: metaphor

text: He has, however, given him a psychotic compulsion to formulate fanciful similes.
label: metaphor

text: Hardly a page goes by without the hapless Francis noticing something which reminds him, improbably, of something else.
label: metaphor

text: Sometimes he is reminded of several things.
label: metaphor

text: One moment an avenue of chestnut trees looks â like a child's drawing of ghosts; the next it appears â frightening but derelict, like extinguished chandeliers; and finally the chestnuts â prance at him, holding up their gleaming branches like hysterics.
label: metaphor

text: Such writing rapidly palls, and I hope that in the novels to come, Motion can curb his reckless passion for it.
label: metaphor

text: Travel: A pilgrimage sans progress Elisabeth de Stroumillo potters round Poitou
label: metaphor

text: PEOPLE tend to look vague when you mention Poitou.
label: metaphor

text: â Umm â¦ not a part of France we know â¦ where exactly is it?
label: metaphor

text: Inland of La Rochelle, you say; north of Cognac and east of Limoges.
label: literal

text: You sort of pass it without realising, going to the Dordogne.
label: metaphor

text: Well, better than that, and one of the best things about it is the fact that so few people, except the French themselves, bother with it.
label: metaphor

text: Even for France, the variety to be found is enormous.
label: metaphor

text: My passion is for its numerous Romanesque churches, in most cases humbly proportioned but elevated into unique works of art by the richness of their exquisitely-sculpted decoration; to go to Poitou/Saintonge and not look at any of its churches would be like going to an African game reserve and ignoring the animals.
label: metaphor

text: For serious drinkers there is the production of cognac to investigate around Cognac, plus the chance to sample pineau, the powerful local aperitif made from young wine laced with cognac.
label: metaphor

text: To the north, where Poitou borders on the Vendee, shapely clumps of trees are almost the only punctuation marks on widespreading marshy landscapes; to the south it bubbles with little rolling hills.
label: metaphor

text: The lower reaches of the Sevre Niortaise are swollen with the waters that once covered the whole area, until medieval monks started to dig a spider-web of ditches to drain it.
label: metaphor

text: Now the Marais Poitevin is a pleasantly low-profile tourist attraction where you can take canal-boat trips from villages that have hardly changed in the 15-odd years I've known them: Maillezais, with a huge and rather dull ruined abbey, and Coulon, where I first ate the delicious local version of moules marinieres called mouclade.
label: metaphor

text: Drifting between grassy polders to which farmers have to ferry their cattle in punts, or following leafy twisting lanes marked only by rusty signs proclaiming the â Venise Verte, you're in an all-green, mysteriously silent world; only the occasional fisherman, twitching his rod above the algae-smothered waters, disturbs the stillness.
label: metaphor

text: There is more greenery further south in the deep forest of Chize( with the fine Renaissance chateau of Dampierre-sur-Boutonne at its edge); and more marshes to the west around Rochefort and Marennes, where those mussels and oysters are raised.
label: metaphor

text: One of the region's strangest townlets sits on those marshes: Brouage.
label: metaphor

text: It had a son to be proud of: Samuel Champlain, founder of Quebec, who was born there around 1569.
label: metaphor

text: She went there when her romance with the young king was quashed for political reasons.
label: metaphor

text: Months later, when Marie had departed, Louis is said to have paused nostalgically at Brouage on his way to Paris after marrying the Spanish Infanta at St Jean-de-Luz.
label: metaphor

text: As you come back from Brouage towards St Jean-d'Angely â on the D18 via the canalside village of Pont-l'Abbe-d'Arnoult, with a lovely Romanesque church faade â a sign at the junction of the D122 points you to the chateau whose improbably perfect lake and gardens stare at you from posters throughout the region: La Roche Courbon.
label: metaphor

text: Its most surprising room, covered from ceiling to floor in 17th-century paintings, should be a salon or library; instead, a dotty stone bathtub was set into one wall at a later date by a lady called Charlotte.
label: metaphor

text: She never used it, having got some of the plumbing details wrong.
label: metaphor

text: Wriggling across country on the D216 to Port-d'Envaux, you come to two more chateaux: 18th-century Panloy, flaking romantically away on its hillock overlooking a bend in the Charente and, almost next door, the much older, moated Crazannes, half-smothered in amazing flamboyant Gothic carving.
label: metaphor

text: Crossing the autoroute and turning north on the D127 brings you to St Jean-d'Angely by way of the isolated church of Fenioux.
label: metaphor

text: Its conically-roofed tower, hugged about by a brood of smaller roofs shaped like candle snuffers, is visible for miles.
label: metaphor

text: St Jean-d'Angely is a charming little town: there are good shops as well as half-timbered houses along its narrow old streets, one spanned by an ancient bell-tower.
label: literal

text: There's also a Renaissance fountain, and an extremely odd conglomeration of church buildings comprising one ancient ruin, one proper church, and the skeleton faade and nave of a rather pompous and unfinished 18th-century abbey.
label: metaphor

text: It makes a conveniently central hub: the Marais Poitevin village of Coulon is 27 miles to the north by the D120, which inexplicably changes its number at the top of a hill to D115.
label: metaphor

text: Saintes, with Gallo-Roman remains, a beautiful Romanesque abbey and an atmospheric medieval quarter, is 17 miles south of St Jean; 15-odd miles to the north-west is Surgeres, all of whose public buildings, including an engagingly asymmetrical church, are within the 16th-century castle walls, scattered among beautiful gardens and parkland â perfect for picnicking.
label: metaphor

text: The villagers' main hobby seems to be fishing with peculiar, saucer-shaped nets suspended from precariously-perched bankside huts.
label: metaphor

text: One fisherman waxed lyrical about the variety of fish in the river.
label: metaphor

text: â Even salmon, he assured me, â but of course those are protected and must be thrown back.
label: metaphor

text: But Aulnay, just over 10 miles north-east of St Jean, is probably the best, its unassuming architecture a perfect frame for the sheer artistry of the carvings round its doors and windows.
label: metaphor

text: Biblical motifs recur â some art-experts call them sermons in stone, and their messages would certainly have been clear to the often-illiterate medieval pilgrims trudging to Santiago de Compostela in Spain.
label: metaphor

text: But these themes are always interspersed with more fanciful ones: grimacing masks, weird animals, exuberant abstract patterns.
label: metaphor

text: I think those 10th- and 11th-century sculptors were motivated not just by piety but also by a certain competitive spirit: if a church was finer than the one in the next village, more pilgrims would surely pause there.
label: metaphor

text: Today's attraction-merchants are doing no more to lure 20th-century tourists than their medieval forebears did for pilgrims.
label: metaphor

text: Law: Always take along a friend to sue: Litigation can pay off even in the unlikeliest circumstances.
label: metaphor

text: Stephen Gold explains
label: literal

text: WHEN things go wrong you can sue more often than you may think.
label: metaphor

text: Money may not have changed hands.
label: metaphor

text: It doesn't matter.
label: literal

text: As long as you can show that they owed you a legal duty to be careful and have been negligent, damages could come your way.
label: metaphor

text: There are a number of points to bear in mind.
label: metaphor

text: Take up references before giving credit, lending money, letting in tenants, taking on staff.
label: metaphor

text: Ask banks, building societies, former landlords, present and past employers.
label: metaphor

text: If you rely to your detriment on a misleading reference which was given negligently, you should be able to sue the referee.
label: metaphor

text: The subject of a bad reference can sue the referee for libel but has to show the referee was upto no good: spite, ill-will or some improper motive will do.
label: metaphor

text: Take along a prosperous adviser on all shopping sprees, demonstrate a high degree of trust and strong reliance in what they say and you may have unexpected protection should the seller go out of business and the goods fall to pieces.
label: metaphor

text: A 26-year-old woman accountant who knew nothing about the mechanical side of vehicles asked her more knowledgeable friend to find a car for her.
label: metaphor

text: She stipulated that it must never have been involved in an accident.
label: metaphor

text: The friend found one at a garage.
label: literal

text: Although he failed to check it had been accident-free, he assured the lady that this was the case.
label: metaphor

text: She bought it.
label: metaphor

text: In May last year the Court of Appeal upheld a judgment against the friend for more than £5,500 damages for negligence because he had owed the accountant a duty of care.
label: metaphor

text: Your conservatory collapses as a result of negligence of the professionals who were engaged by the previous owner to put it up.
label: literal

text: You can sue the professionals â builders, architects, surveyors or engineers â by courtesy of the Defective Premises Act 1972, despite the fact that you never had a contract with them yourself.
label: metaphor

text: There are strict time limits: generally, six years from when damage first occurred; where the damage was initially â latent you are given longer â three years from when you could have discovered it, with a longstop of 15 years.
label: metaphor

text: It may also be possible to claim damages against a local authority for negligently failing to ensure that construction work complied with the relevant building regulations.
label: metaphor

text: A solicitor fails to draw up a will within a reasonable time for a client who subsequently dies.
label: metaphor

text: You lose the gift which the will would have made.
label: metaphor

text: You can sue the solicitor for what you would have collected, had he done his job properly, because the law reckons he owed you, as well as his client, a duty of care.
label: metaphor

text: When you want to borrow on a mortgage, the prospective lenders will have the property valued at your expense.
label: metaphor

text: But if the valuer is negligent and you buy the property relying on his report, you may still be able to sue him for damages.
label: metaphor

text: This is what the House of Lords decided in two cases last April in spite of an attempt to get the valuers off the hook by a disclaimer which said: â I accept that the valuer does not warrant anything stated in his report as being accurate â¦
label: metaphor

text: â Alas, disclaimers may work if, for example, the property being valued is industrial or an expensive house.
label: metaphor

text: Disclaimers may also be used by referees and others to rob you of a claim for damages.
label: metaphor

text: Whoever attempts to hide behind a disclaimer must prove it is fair and reasonable to do so.
label: metaphor

text: But a disclaimer can never take away your rights under the Defective Premises Act 1972 for the collapsing conservatory or prevent anyone being sued for negligence which has caused death or injury.
label: metaphor

text: Have we yet reached the point at which we would be awarded damages against the Meteorological Office because we went camping on the day of an unforecast hurricane?
label: metaphor

text: Or after we followed the duff advice of a legal journalist in a newspaper?
label: metaphor

text: Mercifully, we doubt it!
label: literal

text: The day thrift turned into a nightmare.
label: metaphor

text: GEORGE Tyson is not a gambling man nor does he take unnecessary risks.
label: metaphor

text: He doesn't smoke or drink, and even if he wanted to, two heart attacks and a by-pass operation have made the decision for him.
label: metaphor

text: But that is why, at the age of 68, Mr Tyson is not enjoying what he had hoped would be a comfortable retirement.
label: metaphor

text: A life of saving had, by 1985, given them a small nest-egg of £15,000 on which the interest would help supplement their pensions.
label: metaphor

text: To the Tysons, that meant nothing extravagant â just an extra £135 a month to make life at home in South Ruislip, Middlesex easier.
label: metaphor

text: That money was invested as might be expected of the Tysons.
label: metaphor

text: And for three years, it earned its return, every month.
label: metaphor

text: Until one morning in June 1988 when George Tyson turned on the radio to hear a small, investment business called Barlow Clowes had collapsed.
label: metaphor

text: â It was about 8.30am and I was just getting dressed when it came over on the news, said Mr Tyson, a former clerk of works at Harrow council, London.
label: metaphor

text: Investors in Barlow Clowes since 1985, the Tysons had orginally put £10,000 into the UK fund and £5,000 in Gibraltar-based Barlow Clowes International( BCI).
label: metaphor

text: Fate determined that a short while before the businesses failed, they transferred the £10,000 to BCI because of the better returns being offered.
label: metaphor

text: In the days that followed, the Tysons found that they and 18,000 other investors had been the victims of a financial crash of global proportions.
label: metaphor

text: Of the £190million invested in both funds, BCI investors faced a shortfall of up to £100million.
label: metaphor

text: After the initial shock and disbelief, the Tysons grew angry â at the advisers who convinced them about Barlow Clowes, at the Midland bank manager who gave verbal assurances of its security, at the regulatory authorities responsible for the investment community and at the Department of Trade and Industry which allowed the company to trade.
label: metaphor

text: â I felt it was so safe, they were so professional, said Mr Tyson.
label: metaphor

text: â I feel appalled by the way these professional guardians have treated us.
label: metaphor

text: If you were a gambling man it would not affect you, it would just be lost.
label: metaphor

text: Like so many investors, Mr Tyson found himself having to go back to work to ease the financial strain he had hoped to avoid.
label: metaphor

text: Ironically, it was the Government which he partly blamed for the affair that gave him the chance to return to work after retirement.
label: metaphor

text: A change in the tax rules affecting pensions was shortly followed by a job with the Department of Environment's Property Services Agency, a post which carries him through to March and may see him stay until he is 70.
label: metaphor

text: Putting it as politely as he can, Mr Tyson said the whole affair â encouraged him to return to paid employment.
label: metaphor

text: â I hadn't planned to work at all.
label: metaphor

text: They wanted to do something but felt powerless.
label: metaphor

text: Pursuing legal action would have cost them money they didn't have( unless it meant selling their house which was not an option) but doing nothing left them with the feeling that justice wasn't being done.
label: metaphor

text: So they compromised and gave £100 to the Barlow Clowes Investors Group which was formed last July to represent the investors' interests and co-ordinate the fight for compensation.
label: metaphor

text: That, says Mr Tyson, has been their only blessing.
label: metaphor

text: â They are dedicated people who clearly know what they are talking about and have guided us through it.
label: metaphor

text: Those people are victims, too, but they have certainly kept us together.
label: metaphor

text: That aside, the last year has brought little respite from their own, very personal, crisis.
label: metaphor

text: The Tysons have yet to see any cash payment from the liquidators who have been winding up BCI's affairs.
label: metaphor

text: What little money has been recovered remains the subject of a legal tussle in the courts which may yet take months to resolve.
label: metaphor

text: They have been told that their claim may only amount to around £11,000 of their £15,000 as capital gains tax is likely to be deducted from the total.
label: metaphor

text: But until they get any money back, the Tysons find themselves in the position of the gambler who gambled all and lost.
label: metaphor

text: Except that the Tysons don't gamble.
label: metaphor

text: The Labour Party Conference: Policy review throws a spanner in the Whitehall machinery
label: metaphor

text: AN INCOMING Labour government would turn large areas of Whitehall upside down â but the party's policy review barely considers the implications of its plans for restructuring government departments.
label: metaphor

text: Scattered through the policy review are proposals to: Drastically alter the status and organisation of the Department of Trade and Industry; Create two departments â a Department of Consumer Affairs, and a Department for Legal Administration; Create a Department of Environmental Protection within the existing Department of the Environment; Set up a plethora of new commissions and executive agencies; Set up a Women's Ministry.
label: metaphor

text: Those are only the most overt changes advocated in the review papers.
label: metaphor

text: The only department which explicitly escapes unscathed is the one which Conservatives would most like to abolish: the Department of Energy.
label: metaphor

text: In virtually every case the aim of causing upheaval is explicitly declared, because Labour's aim would be to upset the bureaucratic order it inherits.
label: metaphor

text: New departments and quangos would, according to the review, be designed to act as irritants and antagonists within the Civil Service system.
label: metaphor

text: But the policy review nowhere considers the overall effect of the individual changes proposed, or how they might be co-ordinated.
label: metaphor

text: Nor does it contemplate the knock-on consequences for Labour ministers of attempting to implement their programme while rebuilding the governmental machine.
label: metaphor

text: The â medium term industrial strategy which would form the centrepiece of Labour's economic policy would, according to the Productive and Competitive Economy review group, be â administered by a transformed Department of Trade and Industry.
label: metaphor

text: The review adds: â What we now seek is a DTI which will have an equal, if not superior status, to that of the Treasury.
label: metaphor

text: That approach would seek to knock out a keystone of Civil Service tradition.
label: metaphor

text: Labour policy has long sought to challenge the Treasury's dominance in government.
label: metaphor

text: But its last effort â the Department of Economic Affairs, set up by Harold Wilson and headed by George Brown â ended in futile departmental and ministerial infighting.
label: metaphor

text: There would in addition be a minister for Science and Technology at the newly supreme DTI, with responsibility for determing investment in research.
label: metaphor

text: There is no mention in the education policy of how that might affect the Department of Education and Science.
label: metaphor

text: But while the DTI would override the Treasury, a new â powerful Department of Consumer Affairs would antagonise the DTI.
label: metaphor

text: It would be headed by â a minister of Cabinet rank and act as â the consumers voice with other government departments'.
label: metaphor

text: Its remit for inter-departmental intrusion would be wide, with â a watching brief over government action and the ability to initiate consumer legislation.
label: metaphor

text: Only the Women's Ministry would be given equal license.
label: metaphor

text: It would be able to â require each government department to review its policies, practices, and existing and proposed legislation.
label: metaphor

text: While new departments are born and others extended, one of the oldest â the Home Office â would become a shadow of its present self.
label: metaphor

text: Labour's proposed Department for Legal Administration would take over responsibility for courts and tribunals; court procedures; organisation, training and appointment of the legal profession, magistracy and judiciary; legal aid; legal services; and the Sentencing Council.
label: metaphor

text: That would leave the Home Office with policing, penal policy and the criminal law.
label: metaphor

text: Responsibility for the Sex Discrimination Act, the Equal Pay Act and the Equal Opportunities Commission would be given to the Women's Ministry.
label: metaphor

text: A â new Minister of Environmental Protection would operate inside the DoE.
label: metaphor

text: That could work â though it is easy to imagine conflicts of interest with the housing and planning functions of the department.
label: metaphor

text: â The priority of MAFF must become food, not farming, the policy review says.
label: metaphor

text: â Its main concerns would become food and the people who consume it, not farming and those who produce it.
label: metaphor

text: But the regulatory functions over the food industry, now split between MAFF and the Department of Health, would transfer to a new Food Standards Agency.
label: metaphor

text: That is the first of many agencies, executives, commissions, and other quango-like bodies recommended by the review.
label: metaphor

text: In some cases Labour's quangos merge existing ones, or replace well-established bodies.
label: metaphor

text: The funding of higher education would become the responsibility of one body, rather than two.
label: metaphor

text: Labour's Quality Commission would replace the Audit Commission.
label: metaphor

text: But there would be new regulatory commissions and consumer councils for every utility, along with ombudsmen, and public interest commissioners appointed by the Secretary of State.
label: metaphor

text: There would be Skills UK â a locally structured training commission â a Fair Wages Commission, a Health Technology Commission, a Health Quality Commission, an Education Standards Council, an Independent Sentencing Council, a Children's Commissioner, an Environmental Protection Executive, and a Social Insurance Fund administered by â¦ â an independent commission.
label: metaphor

text: In the Garden Update: Growing classes
label: literal

text: The summer's sprawl begins to be oppressive at this stage in the year and trigger fingers are itching to snip back overgrown mallows, clear out the mildewing foliage of golden rod and reduce the overpowering bulk of bullyboy ground cover.
label: metaphor

text: Keep away from jasmine, already thick in flower bud, and clematis, however untidy.
label: metaphor

text: Buddleias, although messy, should not be cut back until spring.
label: metaphor

text: Dead, ragged heads of the climbing hydrangea can be removed, cutting where the stem joins the main branch.
label: metaphor

text: Virginia creeper needs to be clipped back from windows and hauled out of gutters.
label: metaphor

text: Shrubs such as hydrangea particularly relish rich rations.
label: metaphor

text: It is a good time to plant hardy shrubs too.
label: literal

text: Clematis so bristles with brittle green shoots in spring that planting then is an anxiety rather than a pleasure.
label: metaphor

text: Runner beans and French beans have now given up completely and can be cleared off vegetable plots.
label: metaphor

text: Globe artichokes are sprouting new leaves and may need protection from frost in cold areas.
label: metaphor

text: Summer bedding is looking tired and should be removed so that the ground can be cleaned and fed ready for spring bulbs or wallflowers.
label: metaphor

text: Prices have remained high-indeed the FT-SE index has risen another 55 points since then â allowing even the most passive of private investors, including unit trust holders, to take advantage of the market.
label: metaphor

text: The 10 p.c. gain since election day is looking increasingly sustainable.
label: metaphor

text: It is not that prospects for earnings are 10 p.c. better that they were in the middle of last week, but it is possible to argue that prospects are that much better than they would have been under a Labour government and that the market was discounting such a result.
label: metaphor

text: The FT-SE failed to hold its gains yesterday but shortly after opening it was only six points away from last September's previous record closing level.
label: metaphor

text: Wall Street has been hitting new peaks this week too, which has given support to the London market( and even Japan's Nikkei index, in a typically erratic period, has gained nearly 800 points while London added its 245) but London has real strengths of its own.
label: metaphor

text: The City view is that the fall in corporate earnings has stopped and that next year's increase could be around 15 p.c.
label: metaphor

text: The market's price-earnings multiple was 16 last night but it would drop below 14 if that increase in earnings really happens.
label: metaphor

text: The increase will not be matched by dividend rises â too many companies have been paying more than they could afford over the past two years and need to repair their reserves and ratios â but 7 p.c. growth looks reasonable.
label: metaphor

text: The market yield, a historic 4 p.c., could return back above 5 p.c., therefore giving basic-rate taxpayers a real return with the prospect of real growth too.
label: metaphor

text: Not all problems have gone away of course: yesterday's £6.4 billion public sector borrowing requirement is not much higher than expectations, but it is almost as large as the deficit for the previous 11 months and â with this year's deficit forecast to be double last year's â shows why the Bank of England so eagerly sold £2 billion or more of gilts on election night and why it needs a regular stream of massive sales.
label: metaphor

text: The change in employment may not always be so favourable as yesterday's either, but the market is now starting to feel bullish and looking for a FT-SE of 3,000 by next year.
label: metaphor

text: THIRTY FIVE people died and others were maimed for life in the Clapham rail disaster in December last year because work was done in a slovenly, haphazard way and was then left unchecked.
label: metaphor

text: The disaster was all the more stunning because people had come to assume that such things didn't happen.
label: metaphor

text: Clapham, indeed, accounts for nearly half the 77 fatalities of the last ten years: compare that with the 5,000 deaths and 300,000 injuries every year on the roads.
label: metaphor

text: Yet yesterday's report on the Clapham crash, confirming the picture which emerged throughout the Hidden inquiry, makes an event which seemed at the time totally unexpected look almost inevitable.
label: metaphor

text: Under strain for a start because it was technically ill-equipped to avert disaster or to cope with the consequences when disaster struck; under strain from commercial pressures which, as the inquiry puts it, â compromised safety; under strain above all because the people on the spot couldn't or wouldn't cope, were weary from gruesome working hours( the senior signal technician who heads the list of the culpable had had only one day off in the past 13 weeks), lacked adequate training, or simply couldn't be bothered.
label: metaphor

text: The bulk of the blame for all that is placed on British Rail, which knowingly permitted these things to continue.
label: metaphor

text: Though individuals are nailed, the greatest villain of all is the system.
label: metaphor

text: In a desperately competitive climate, where anyone bright and competent could go down the road and pick up a better paid job with kinder hours and more congenial working conditions from someone like British Telecom, the railways ran a service dependent on people who belonged to a narrow and inbred working culture, with outdated procedures of training and promotion, and an institutional reliance on overtime working, whose wholly disgraceful dimensions are symbolised by the fact that maximum weekly hours were only recently cut to 72 hours a week.
label: metaphor

text: The Transport Secretary, Mr Cecil Parkinson, assured the Commons yesterday that financial considerations would not stand in the way of implementing Sir Anthony Hidden's 93 recommendations.
label: metaphor

text: But the job of lifting the standards of people employed, giving them proper training, and paying a wage which breaks dependence on overtime and lifts morale: this together must far exceed the costs of the technology, and it isn't by any means clear what the bill will be or where the money will come from.
label: metaphor

text: Government fixes the format in which BR has to work; and if, as the Hidden report attests, many of its problems today reflect lack of past planning, lack of farsighted investment, living from hand to mouth, then that is not just BR's doing.
label: metaphor

text: Government compounds all these problems when it sets down working parameters which fail to reflect the value the country gets from a system that is run efficiently, can shift people to destinations with exemplary speed and safety â as Europe consistently demonstrates.
label: metaphor

text: It is sad, and somewhat ominous, that so little of that should have been reflected in the sombre statement which Mr Parkinson made in the House yesterday ..
label: metaphor

text: The only accident and emergency relief was provided by the police, part-time St John ambulance volunteers running 20 vehicles, and the Red Cross.
label: metaphor

text: Outside the capital, accident and emergency services were being provided in most areas, but the ban on emergency work was tightened.
label: metaphor

text: The service was facing its biggest crisis since the ambulances came to a stop in the Winter of Discontent ten years ago.
label: metaphor

text: Like Labour in 1979, the Conservatives have put military ambulances on standby.
label: metaphor

text: They move in today.
label: literal

text: What has gone wrong?
label: metaphor

text: There are three key causes of the shambles: Mr Kenneth Clarke; the failure to separate emergency from non-emergency work; and the Whitley Council negotiating machinery.
label: metaphor

text: The Health Secretary accused the unions of â posturing and pretending to run a 999 service yesterday.
label: metaphor

text: By refusing to keep open two-way radio links, the crews had effectively ended a proper emergency service.
label: metaphor

text: The move was signalled last week and, true to their promised response, management suspended the workers involved in the disruption.
label: metaphor

text: But â posturing and pretending went far beyond the unions.
label: metaphor

text: Mr Clarke has been indulging in just that himself, putting up the luckless Duncan Nichol, chief executive of the health service, to take the initial flak under the pretence that the dispute is not his direct responsibility.
label: metaphor

text: Yet it was Mr Clarke, not Mr Nichol, who was involved in the critical decisions â the cash limit for the NHS, the 6.5 per cent offer to ambulance workers( compared to seven per cent for nurses, eight per cent for doctors and nine per cent for ancillary workers); and today's introduction of military ambulances.
label: metaphor

text: Ambulance workers on emergency work do deserve a much higher increase.
label: metaphor

text: They have progressed far beyond routine first aid.
label: metaphor

text: Their paramedical skills cover highly technical procedures: intubation, infusion and defebrillation.
label: metaphor

text: The crews are able to resuscitate heart attack patients, replace fluid intraveneously after severe blood loss, and insert tubes to maintain air supplies in unconconscious casualties.
label: metaphor

text: Yet the ambulance worker is only being offered £10,000, when a fire officer is being given £13,000 and a Metropolitan police constable can earn £25,000.
label: literal

text: But only two million out of the 20 million journeys which ambulance crews carry out each year are emergency calls.
label: metaphor

text: Nine out of 10 are routine calls, many of which could be carried out by mini cabs.
label: metaphor

text: Mr Duncan Nichol wants to separate the emergency from the non-emergency work.
label: metaphor

text: He is right to pursue this line.
label: metaphor

text: Wiltshire and Northumbria have already shown how much can be achieved.
label: metaphor

text: The ramshackle Whitley Council negotiating machinery is the other reason why the ambulance workers have lost out.
label: metaphor

text: Until this year, the three independent review bodies which make recommendations for nurses, doctors and the professions allied to medicine have given much higher awards than the Whitley Councils.
label: metaphor

text: As Lord McCarthy noted some 13 years ago, the management side of the councils comprise â employers who do not pay and paymasters who do not employ.
label: metaphor

text: A much more flexible system which would allow local managers to negotiate local rates â on a national pay spine â is needed.
label: metaphor

text: One Mr Clarke can not duck away from if he wants to avoid a second Winter of Discontent ..
label: metaphor

text: PRINCE CHARLES is jolly good at opening things.
label: metaphor

text: He needs to be for the next four days in Hong Kong, because he will be hard at work cutting ribbons and laying foundation stones.
label: metaphor

text: He is even re-opening the already opened Eastern Harbour tunnel and subway crossing.
label: metaphor

text: It is all standard royal stuff, but not much help to the millions who fear that Hong Kong will not remain open after 1997.
label: metaphor

text: The whole point of a visit to Hong Kong now, five months after Tiananmen Square, should be to declare with royal authority that Britain shares the concerns of the Hong Kong people and is determined to do something about them.
label: metaphor

text: When the Prince and Princess of Wales quite rightly scrapped their tour of the mainland, they had the opportunity to make a contrasting point in Hong Kong.
label: metaphor

text: Unless they can say something relevant in the next four days, the many Hong Kong critics who believe the visit is a waste of dollars will be absolutely right.
label: metaphor

text: It did not help at all that upon arrival yesterday the royal couple instantly touched base in that comforting symbol of past British power, the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank.
label: metaphor

text: If there is a failure of imagination to use the royal visit creatively it will also be a failure of nerve.
label: metaphor

text: Britain still can not decide when to play the mandarinate game of silence with the Chinese and when to break the rules( as Beijing does all the time.)
label: metaphor

text: The ideal tactics should be a mixture of both, but only if a clear message can be communicated to the Hong Kong people that someone is standing up for them somewhere.
label: metaphor

text: Instead the latest developments in Sino-British relations have left them even more confused than before.
label: metaphor

text: China claims that the Hong Kong Government recently gave a written commitment to limit the activities of the pro-democracy movement in the territory.
label: metaphor

text: The government denies this, but has published the text of a letter from its Political Adviser to the New China News Agency( Beijing's embassy in Hong Kong) suggesting that it did.
label: metaphor

text: In a tone of meek appeasement, the letter draws attention to the arrest by Hong Kong police of anti-China demonstrators outside the agency's National Day reception.
label: metaphor

text: It also reminds Beijing that permission has been refused for local protesters to erect a replica Statue of Democracy on a permanent site.
label: metaphor

text: It ends by assuring Beijing that the Hong Kong Government will have â a prudent regard for the special circumstances of Hong Kong and the interests and concerns of the Chinese Government.
label: metaphor

text: Meanwhile the flood of letters of a very different sort from anxious Hong Kong citizens to this and every other newspaper office continues.
label: metaphor

text: So do the Chinese press statements asserting that Hong Kong is â entirely a business between China and Britain and should not be discussed, formally or informally, at any international forum.
label: metaphor

text: The only two Hong Kong legislators who consistently dare to speak out, Mr Martin Lee and Mr Szeto Wah, have been threatened with expulsion from the committee now drafting China's post-1997 Basic Law.
label: metaphor

text: Our latest Foreign Secretary has yet to publicly pick up the file marked Hong Kong.
label: literal

text: There is still endless dithering on how broad a â safety net Britain will extend to its citizens.
label: metaphor

text: They may rightly feel that it is all really rather appalling.
label: metaphor

text: The US sets its compass on two trading oceans Notebook.
label: metaphor

text: CANBERRA may seem an awful long way from exchanges on the floor of the House of Commons over the European Monetary System.
label: metaphor

text: But were it not for the perceived economic might of a more unified Economic Community, the dozen or so nations of the Pacific Rim, who have been meeting in Australia, might not have bothered.
label: metaphor

text: The first, albeit tenative, steps towards forming a new Pacific-based economic union display an astute awareness of the way events are moving within Europe: movements with which Number 10 has yet to come to grips.
label: metaphor

text: Not so long ago it seemed as if the world was to divide into three main trading blocks: the EC based around the West German economy; a Northern American block based around the US-Canadian free trade area, and a Pacific unit incorporating the Asian tigers with Japan and the yen at the centre.
label: metaphor

text: But the Metternich-like skills of the US Secretary of State, Mr James Baker, are ensuring that America maintains a strong stake in each forum.
label: metaphor

text: It firstly boldly asked for a seat at the top table at the European Community: a suggestion rudely rebuffed.
label: metaphor

text: The US has talked of a genuine North American free trade zone incorporating the US, Canada and Mexico which would have the best of all worlds with high-technology skills and a cheap labour force south of the Rio Grande.
label: metaphor

text: Now it is making a third bid for influence.
label: metaphor

text: It has turned up in Canberra with Japan to develop Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation( APEC) and a new 12-nation organisation which will mimic the role of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in Europe.
label: metaphor

text: Preliminary steps taken to conduct studies on trade, technology and investment flows in the region may seem insignificant.
label: metaphor

text: But Mr Baker plainly views it as otherwise.
label: metaphor

text: He noted that the Canberra meeting â is the start of something which could grow into a very significant development not only for the region but for the global economy.
label: metaphor

text: If the more economically puny ASEAN countries( Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, Thailand and the Philippines) were to bury their reservations, then the high growth from other partners, including such tigers as Thailand and South Korea alongside the more mature economies of Japan and Australia, could mean a dynamic coalition.
label: metaphor

text: It would then be up to the US and Canada to decide whether they want to face towards the Atlantic or Pacific â or be caught between two great trading oceans.
label: metaphor

text: Heading for default.
label: metaphor

text: THE QUESTION of just who would even want to be a partner with the US was underlined last night as the American Administration headed for default for the first time in its history.
label: metaphor

text: Congress was frantically trying to complete a bill raising the federal debt ceiling in time for President Bush to sign today.
label: metaphor

text: Leaders on Capitol Hill virtually put all other business on hold as it sought to hammer out a debt ceiling increase.
label: metaphor

text: The Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, a level headed figure, warned that the imbroglio may lead to higher interest costs for the taxpayer.
label: metaphor

text: What should have been a routine exercise in extending the Government's borrowing power to $3.1 thousand billion became bogged down in wrangling over legislative initiatives lawmakers wanted to attach to the bill.
label: metaphor

text: As a result of the stalemate, the Treasury has been forced to postpone $40billion in debt auctions this week.
label: metaphor

text: Lack of congressional action also forced the Treasury to suspend new sales of US savings bonds and of special securities for state and local governments.
label: metaphor

text: This market sensitive dispute has taken place as President Bush and Congress continued to spar on a primary cause for government borrowing â the budget deficit.
label: metaphor

text: At a press conference to mark his election victory a year ago, Mr Bush threatened to veto the budget unless it contained real cuts.
label: metaphor

text: Otherwise Congress would have to face the consequences of automatic across-the-board cuts under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget deficit reduction law.
label: metaphor

text: America may have changed Presidents a year ago, but the fiscal thicket remains as inpenetrable as ever.

text: NO LONGER can the Government disguise the crisis surrounding electricity privatisation.
label: metaphor

text: Ministers have already had to pull Britain's fleet of Magnox reactors out of the float and delay the sell-off date by up to six months.
label: metaphor

text: But it has now become clear that further drastic amendments are needed to flotation plans.
label: metaphor

text: After months of turning deaf ears to warnings by the City and industry, the Department of Energy has at last conceded that nuclear plant can not be included in the share float without state support.
label: metaphor

text: This leaves the Energy Secretary, Mr John Wakeham, with two options: he can either agree to underwrite any cost escalations in nuclear handling costs after privatisation, or he can swallow his pride, and pull all nuclear plant out of the impending sale.
label: metaphor

text: Whatever the outcome, the Government's willingness to continue pushing through the float during this Parliament shows how ministers are prepared to put political expediency before the interests of the industry.
label: metaphor

text: For the nuclear element in electricity privatisation is the coping stone on which the flotation plans are based.
label: metaphor

text: National Power was given 70 per cent of the CEGB's generating capacity in order to give it an economic mix of power.
label: metaphor

text: The other 30 per cent is to be operated by PowerGen, the other CEGB successor company.
label: metaphor

text: Take away or subsidise all nuclear power stations and you lose the commercial logic of the privatisation plans.
label: metaphor

text: Electricity privatisation needs to go back to the drawing board.
label: metaphor

text: At the very least, the CEGB should be divided into a wider range of generating companies to stimulate competition.
label: metaphor

text: Is it worth sacrificing the long-term future of Britain's biggest stateowned industry to make political capital in the run-up to the next election?
label: metaphor

text: Luxury life awaits private jail inmates
label: metaphor

text: DUVETS, phonecards, hot showers and video films will greet inmates at Britain's first privately-run prison when it opens on Monday.
label: metaphor

text: The Wolds, a remand centre at Brough, North Humberside, is far removed from the insanitary conditions which prevail at many jails.
label: metaphor

text: The 320 inmates will be allowed out of their cells for 14 hours a day with a minimum of six hours education and 13 hours exercise a week.
label: metaphor

text: Nail clippers, combs, toothpaste and toothbrushes, razors and washbags are neatly laid out on tables in the cells to await the arrival of inmates, many of whom will not be carrying such items because they may not have expected to be remanded in custody.
label: metaphor

text: â The cells are luxurious compared to some of the things we put up with in the Army, said one staff member during a Press tour of the jail.
label: metaphor

text: The prison has a medical block with 24 beds and a gym with equipment that staff said would be the envy of many council leisure centres.
label: metaphor

text: Group 4 Remand Services Ltd, the security firm selected by the Home Office to manage The Wolds in a £5 million-a-year contract, likes to think of its prisoners as customers.
label: metaphor

text: â It may seem a little odd for prison staff to be looking at their prisoners as customers, but they are the direct consumers of our service, explained Mr Stephen Twinn, prison director, who spent 23 years in the public sector at various grades of prison governor.
label: metaphor

text: The 60 male warders or â custody officers as they are called, wear a dapper outfit of black blazers, grey trousers, white shirts and grey tie.
label: metaphor

text: Women managers have a choice as to whether they wear trousers or a skirt.
label: metaphor

text: Name badges are worn by staff.
label: literal

text: An atmosphere poisoned by mistrust
label: metaphor

text: The disposal of toxic wastes is one of the most intractable problems facing industrialised societies.
label: metaphor

text: Even though some of the most dangerous and persistent toxins, including polychlorinated biphenyls, PCBs, are no longer manufactured, quantities of them still exist, and must be got rid of.
label: metaphor

text: On this page, Nick Roe visits a plant which, despite strenuous public relations efforts, has failed to convince its neighbours that it has come clean.
label: metaphor

text: And Richard North looks at current provisions for the destruction of PCBs, and at the history of British involvement in a rather uncomfortable growth industry The security guard at the entrance to one of Britain's mightiest hazardous waste disposal plants pressed a button and the gate opened.
label: metaphor

text: Then he pressed another knob and a big toy doll in his office window dropped its trousers.
label: metaphor

text: Beyond the barrier lay some of the most toxic chemicals known, awaiting destruction by fire.
label: metaphor

text: A vast, smoke-blackened furnace; 100 people to do the work; massive investment â the company spent £2m last year on cleaning up smoke emissions.
label: metaphor

text: Plus a backdrop of houses covering the valley walls on either side, a reminder that wherever industrialised societies decide to deal with their most intractable problems, they are unlikely to find a place to do so which is not in somebody's back yard.
label: metaphor

text: Britain grinds out almost five million tonnes of hazardous waste each year, of which about 63,000 tonnes are so difficult to store or treat that they are burnt at high temperatures here in Gwent or at one of three other centres: Ellesmere Port; Fawley, near Southampton; and the unfortunately named Killamarsh, near Sheffield.
label: metaphor

text: Five more incinerators currently proposed in various parts of the country will double capacity.
label: literal

text: Then there are the imports: 83,000 tonnes of toxic waste enter British ports annually for incineration or other treatment, a figure which has increased 20-fold in just eight years.
label: metaphor

text: Liverpool dockers recently turned back parts of a 1,500-tonne consignment of Canadian PCBs( polychlorinated biphenyls) bound for this plant in Gwent.
label: metaphor

text: In doing so, they underlined a fact which is likely to attract more and more attention as tankers continue to shift toxins from town to town, country to country: the waste chain is long.
label: metaphor

text: It snakes in and out of ports, along our busiest highways and through our most crowded cities.
label: metaphor

text: Anxieties which are currently felt most acutely by those living near destruction plants themselves may not always remain so localised.
label: metaphor

text: Local people mutter and march, make speeches and throw things; staff face sarcasm in nearby pubs; and for years there have been demands for a public inquiry.
label: metaphor

text: Rechem has responded with a rather desperate open-door policy aimed at soothing fears, and more recently by issuing about a dozen writs against the fiercest critics.
label: metaphor

text: â We are an aggressive company, admitted David Wheeler, operations director at this plant and at Rechem's other incinerator, at Fawley.
label: metaphor

text: For a place so hated, the Pontypool plant looks innocuous inside, like a cross between an oil refinery and a crematorium.
label: metaphor

text: Mr Wheeler, an engineer who worked for many years in the oil business, is a pleasant, slightly worried-looking man who can not bear the fact that no one seems to realise just what lengths he goes to in order to keep the plant squeaky clean and emission-free.
label: metaphor

text: In hard hats and protective glasses, we walked past the huge â fume cupboard where the most noxious barrels are opened, and arrived at the vast, closed mouth of the furnace itself.
label: metaphor

text: There was a fault on the computer governing the plant, said Mr Wheeler, and the fire had automatically shut down.
label: metaphor

text: These pipes stretching thinly in a bridge across the service road injected a mix of chemicals into the walls of the furnace itself; did I know that fuel was only used in the start-up process, after which the chemicals themselves provided the fire?
label: metaphor

text: Workers in blue overalls drifted around us and cracked jokes in gentle Welsh accents.
label: metaphor

text: In the furnace control office I found shift foreman Keith Thomas and asked innocently if he had any physical problems: â Not since my vasectomy.
label: metaphor

text: He lived locally, so how did neighbours view his job here?
label: metaphor

text: â You get sarcasm mainly.
label: metaphor

text: A lot of my friends are pleased that the company is doing the job they are doing.
label: metaphor

text: Others are not so well informed.
label: literal

text: You couldn't hope to convert them.
label: metaphor

text: At a nearby house, Leonard Hough, a retired schoolmaster, had earlier told me about â the fog which he says comes from the factory.
label: metaphor

text: They've improved the chimney recently and it's very much better than it was but we still get the smells.
label: metaphor

text: And since they've refused repeatedly to have a public inquiry into what is going on there we're not certain of the safety of what's coming out.
label: metaphor

text: We get smoke from the steel works across the valley, but we know what that is and we're not afraid of it.
label: metaphor

text: Keith Thomas pressed a button and a huge door clanked upwards so that I could peer into the heart of the furnace.
label: metaphor

text: Piles of ruddy-brown ash lay heaped on the floor.
label: metaphor

text: Pumps sucked air inwards.
label: metaphor

text: Heat shone out.
label: literal

text: In here, they burn about 30,000 tonnes of chemicals a year, a quarter originating outside Britain.
label: metaphor

text: The waste arrives at the rate of up to seven tanker-loads every day â that is seven lorries passing thousands of doorsteps.
label: metaphor

text: Right here, in this gaping mouth, lies the end of the chain.
label: metaphor

text: The wastes include lindane, DDT, out-of-date drugs, carcinogenic chemicals, old cigars and even pornography( a different kind of pollution).
label: metaphor

text: PCBs are so difficult to destroy, that Rechem's emission-monitoring systems are geared to detecting them on the grounds that if you destroy PCBs you destroy everything.
label: metaphor

text: If you did not burn chemicals like PCBs, what else would you do with them?
label: metaphor

text: â We are not in the business of polluting the environment, Mr Wheeler insisted.
label: metaphor

text: Environmental organisations, however, put the emphasis elsewhere.
label: metaphor

text: â There is no incinerator which completely destroys toxic wastes, Madeleine Cobbing, Greenpeace's toxics campaigner, told me.
label: literal

text: â The crux of our argument is that we don't need to have toxic wastes and the fact that plants like Rechem exist, providing easy options for companies, is acting as a disincentive for companies to clean up.
label: metaphor

text: But â another but â what about the PCBs that already exist?
label: metaphor

text: Although they are no longer manufactured, they are still present, for example in electrical equipment.
label: literal

text: No one could therefore call for the closure of incineration plants at a stroke, because noxious chemicals have to go somewhere.
label: metaphor

text: So a part of the argument switches to the kind of incinerators you allow while industry is forced to clean itself up.
label: metaphor

text: Also, how these should function and â perhaps most important of all â where you put them.
label: metaphor

text: Mr Wheeler, now moving to the rear of the plant to show off the £2m smoke-cleaning section, which had just broken down, pointed out that his company achieved destruction of at least 99.9999 per cent of all materials.
label: metaphor

text: The company's figures imply that when you have burnt 99.9999 per cent of a 30,000-tonne annual throughput, a figure of 0.03 of a tonne remains.
label: metaphor

text: In 1986, according to Friends of the Earth, a survey of the homes clustered on the surrounding hills found that three-quarters of 800 residents were opposed to the Rechem plant.
label: metaphor

text: â The plant should be relocated because it's in the wrong place, Llew Smith, the local Euro-MP, told me.
label: metaphor

text: What did Mr Wheeler make of that?
label: metaphor

text: â If we do it properly any spot is the right spot, he insisted.
label: literal

text: Stack emissions of PCBs were below the American standard for breathing air- 1,000 times lower than the British equivalent.
label: metaphor

text: Regular soil and grass tests showed no difference between PCB contamination in the immediate area and elsewhere in Wales â though there are no established â safe levels for these.
label: metaphor

text: Five air-monitoring plants had been installed( he took me to see them).
label: metaphor

text: And here were drums of chemicals, each labelled, each with a job number to check against sampling.
label: metaphor

text: In 1987, aluminium melted in the furnace, reacted with water and exploded, sending a black cloud over nearby houses.
label: metaphor

text: Later, drums supposedly containing carcinogenic drugs were not opened for checking before burning( for health reasons) and three were â misdescribed.
label: metaphor

text: They, too, reacted with water, and a plant operator was burned by a cloud of acid gas.
label: metaphor

text: We walked past a tanker where a huge man named Andy Matthews was pumping vinyl acetate into a 10,000-gallon vat, wreathed in its sweet, sickly smell: â I've been here two years, he said.
label: metaphor

text: â My father was an industrial chemist and he said if you want to go and work for them, go and work for them.
label: literal

text: He shrugged.
label: literal

text: I might drop a pipe â a little bit of a splash.
label: metaphor

text: In a large, prefabricated shed we wandered past stacks of 45-gallon drums of PCBs, two drums high, about 10 deep; and there were contaminated transformers waiting to be cut up and roasted in the flames.
label: metaphor

text: Back along the waste chain, the Liverpool dockers who objected to the import of exactly this type of chemical should be aware that PCBs are moving about our roads all the time.
label: metaphor

text: There was no difference between the liquid in these drums and the liquid in the cargoes they refused to touch.
label: metaphor

text: In Liverpool, a dockers' spokesman with the Transport and General Workers Union admitted: â Drivers aren't happy handling some of these commodities, but at least a lorry-driver has more idea of what he is handling than a docker, who could have a consignment and just not know what it is.
label: metaphor

text: Yet he did not oppose all toxic waste movement( after all, the same union represents workers at Rechem itself); he simply didn't like the idea that big industrial nations like Canada could dump their dirty problems on this country and his members.
label: metaphor

text: Driving away, I noticed that the vast chimney was still not functioning, but when I called at a neighbouring house a woman showed me videos she had taken of smoke coming from the plant, settling in her garden.
label: metaphor

text: Certainly the incinerator seems well controlled.
label: literal

text: Certainly there is no scientific evidence that living nearby increases the risk of sickness.
label: literal

text: Certainly, Mr Wheeler convinced me that his company was going to huge lengths to keep itself clean.
label: metaphor

text: â We must run it safely in the short term and long term, he said, â because if people are able to demonstrate that we are causing an environment problem we will be shut down.
label: metaphor

text: In April 1985 a tanker spilled 200 litres of PCBs over the main Trans-Canada Highway on the border between Ontario and Manitoba.
label: metaphor

text: A section of the road was shut for a week and motorists were warned to clean their cars and to dispose of the rags in plastic bags.
label: metaphor

text: MANY will take it as a further surrender to Common Market bureaucracy that an inspectorate will soon be established to regulate the smell of farm manure.
label: metaphor

text: The smell released by a pig or chicken farm is indescribable, and can affect 10 square miles of countryside around.
label: metaphor

text: One may doubt whether modern farming has any useful purpose nowadays when everybody is on a diet.
label: metaphor

text: It mostly seems to involve producing food for animals to eat, whose excrement is then collected to assist the growth of more food for animals.
label: metaphor

text: Small children can sometimes be persuaded to eat cow cake in the same way that old people will eat cat food, but the chief result of all this farming was to produce huge food mountains which we could then refuse to give to the Third World, or to the socialists of Eastern Europe, in order to teach them the error of their ways.
label: metaphor

text: However, there is a new plan to turn land over to wind farming.
label: metaphor

text: It involves nothing more than putting up 80-foot masts all over the land.
label: metaphor

text: A 1,500-acre grouse moor will generate enough electricity in this way to power a town of 6,000 people.
label: metaphor

text: The farmer receives a rent of £15,000 a year and is relieved of the need to do any work for it.
label: metaphor

text: All the food we need will be provided by monster underground funguses producing a regular crop of mushrooms without human assistance.
label: metaphor

text: The masts may seem unsightly to those unused to them, but I am sure it is simply a matter of getting accustomed.
label: metaphor

text: Cows were thought very unsightly when they were first introduced.
label: metaphor

text: MUSICALS/ Bows of Holly: Mark Steyn reviews London's latest musical biography, Buddy, at The Victoria Palace
label: literal

text: THE TEXANS drawl â Y'all, blacks go â Yo, Hispanics leer â Hey, ameeeeeeeego!.
label: literal

text: And towering above these stage cliches is, of course, the driven genius whose music can not be stemmed by the forces of reaction.
label: metaphor

text: No matter; only the accents change â and the pants: here, the squares wear slacks, the good guys blue-jeans.
label: metaphor

text: Warned not to sing rock'n'roll on a c&w station, Buddy Holly insists, â I got ta play ma music.
label: metaphor

text: Misunderstood by Decca Records, he maintains, â I wan na play ma music ma way.
label: metaphor

text: Even when the hits start, he's not content.
label: metaphor

text: â We got ta take our music more serious, he tells the Crickets, who remain unconvinced.
label: metaphor

text: â You got money, you got fame, he pleads, â what you want to booze for?
label: metaphor

text: We're midway through Act II and a solitary six-pack has yet to hove into view.
label: metaphor

text: But this is a plot development â the plot development â and, if it involves turning a couple of Aled Jones types into Oliver Reeds, why let logic get in the way?
label: metaphor

text: As it happens, there is a kind of logic behind Buddy.
label: metaphor

text: The most common reason for a biomusical is opportunism: take a star like Judy Garland or John Lennon, and you pick up a hit title and a hit score ready-made.
label: metaphor

text: Now, Alan Janes's play matches the well-loved songs with equally well-loved dialogue in a K-Tel Golden Greats collection of Dramatists' Reliables.
label: metaphor

text: Choke up at The Price Of Fame: â I give â em everything and they stick a knife in my back.
label: metaphor

text: Fight back those tears at The Inevitable Parting: â You and me, boy, I reckon we've come to the end of our road.
label: metaphor

text: Marvel at The Little Woman Behind The Man: â I'd like to sing a song fer a special girlfriend who's kinda important to me.
label: metaphor

text: â All that happens in the play is based on fact, Janes pledges solemnly in the programme notes.
label: metaphor

text: â As we know, truth is often stranger than fiction.
label: literal

text: Most of us prefer to watch Dallas than our neighbours' home-movies, because, when it comes down to it, we know that truth is generally a lot duller than fiction.
label: metaphor

text: Occasionally, though, a dramatist will uncover someone with an interesting story, regardless of how unknown or vaguely remembered the subject is.
label: metaphor

text: How many of us can now recall the real Maria von Trapp or Fanny Brice?
label: metaphor

text: They live only through The Sound Of Music and Funny Girl.
label: metaphor

text: Buddy Holly comes somewhere between the subjects of those and more parasitic biographies.
label: metaphor

text: His records are still played, but his personality, unexposed through movies or extensive TV interviews, is almost entirely unknown.
label: metaphor

text: He was born in Lubbock, married a nice Spanish girl and died young in a â plane crash in 1959.
label: metaphor

text: All that counts are the records, a rhythmically unusual Tex-Mex fusion of rock'n'roll and older western elements, pioneering what became the standard pop instrumentation of two guitars, bass and drums.
label: metaphor

text: Of the two prototype rock songwriters, it's the more worldly Chuck Berry you turn to for the authentic picture of teenage pleasures in Eisenhower's America: â Gon na write a little letter, Gon na mail it to my local deejay.
label: metaphor

text: Or: â Cruising and playing the radio With no particular place to go.
label: metaphor

text: Buddy invites us to regard Holly in the same light, mocking( in a horribly nudging re-creation) Lubbock old-timers like The Hayriders, who sing: â When the sun goes down on Blue Ridge Mountain It's the time to whistle in your ear.
label: metaphor

text: If you didn't know the tunes, you'd assume Holly's lyrics decorated some innocent backporch spooners from the turn-of-the-century: â Stars appear and the shadows are fallin' You can hear my honey callin'.
label: metaphor

text: Or: â You give me all your lovin' And your turtle-dovin'.
label: metaphor

text: Or: â When Cupid shot his dart He shot it at your heart.
label: metaphor

text: Not only are these songs impossible to use dramatically, they're also too vague to use as incidental music, to underline or punctuate aspects of Holly's life or the 1950s more generally.
label: metaphor

text: â I wrote it for you, he assures his gal before the ballads, but how can you tell?
label: metaphor

text: All you can do with these songs is sing them, and Buddy fails even to manage that with any subtlety.
label: metaphor

text: And, for all the appeal of his singing and playing, Paul Hipp comes out pretty dull between the numbers.
label: metaphor

text: To camouflage the failures of the play, Andy Walmsley has created a set which resembles a pile-up of roadside hoardings: Oldsmobile, Van Heusen shirts, Texaco Premium Type.
label: metaphor

text: Rob Bettinson, the director, has deduced that he ought to have these images plus disc-jockeys, radio commercials, midwestern hops, but he doesn't seem to know why.
label: metaphor

text: Like most shows which are manufactured with an eye to commercial success( Winnie, High Society, to name only Buddy's predecessors at the Victoria Palace), this one will probably fail.
label: metaphor

text: It's not as if there aren't aspects of his career that aren't worth exploring: how did he come to use drums, then almost unknown in Texan country line-ups?
label: metaphor

text: Was it true, as the chart performance of â Heartbeat( his last release) suggests, that his three-year career was already on the wane?
label: metaphor

text: And surely any dramatist ought to be able to move us with that final night of Holly's life, when his musicians( including Waylon Jennings) gave their places on the â plane to the Big Bopper and Ritchie Valens.
label: metaphor

text: The author's job is not merely to offer an illustrated Who's Who entry, but to turn elements of a man's life into a dramatic entity.
label: metaphor

text: And, if Holly's too boring for that, perhaps the best approach would be to write about his impact on others.
label: metaphor

text: That, after all, is what Don McLean did so brilliantly in â American Pie, a personal reaction to â the day the music died.
label: metaphor

text: â I have a very important assignment for you, Paula, Arlene Frampton-Cox said.

text: She inserted a Du Maurier cigarette into her long tortoiseshell holder and sat back, looking at Paula, who was seated in the visitor's chair on the other side of the desk, long legs crossed elegantly.

text: Paula looked every inch a model these days, Arlene thought with a touch of proprietorial pride.

text: Her long hair, shining gold, was swept back and caught at the nape of her neck with a bow, make-up, expertly applied, accentuated the classically beautiful lines of her face, and she wore her well-cut suit with all the panache that was expected of her.

text: A good suit was a working model's uniform â Paula now bought two each season and wore them with perfectly matching accessories, hat, bag and shoes.

text: Perfectly groomed from head to toe and with all that assurance, she was ready to take on the world, Arlene thought with satisfaction, for she looked on Paula as her very own creation.

text: Her dark, grey-streaked hair, which she wore in a long bob, had been cut by Vidal Sassoon and she wore a beautifully tailored black suit relieved only by a little white flounce at the neckline.

text: Madame Mattli might be a stickler for detail, with a generous helping of the artistic temperament which kept her tight-coiled as a spring and which would explode into frenzy if the smallest detail was not as it should be, but she also had a kind face and deep perceptive eyes.

text: Half way through the day's programme of shows, while the dressers went off to grab a sandwich and the model girls, who would not dare to eat while they were showing, revived themselves with cups of black coffee, Madame Mattli took Paula to one side.

text: A month later Paula, smartly dressed in a new tweed suit with the obligatory matching bag and shoes, and lugging both her modelling case and a brand new cream leather suitcase, took the train to London to begin her new career.

text: She had booked herself a bed at a YWCA hostel for the time being.

text: From the hostel it was only a short tube ride to South Audley Street where Madame Mattli had her showrooms â yet another advantage, Paula thought, trying to weigh up the points in favour of the hostel, which she hated on sight.
label: metaphor

text: Sharing a small spartan room with two other girls â Northerners whose accent Paula found almost incomprehensible and with whom she had nothing in common, making breakfast in the communal kitchen, queuing for the bath, adhering to a strict curfew after which time the doors were locked and bolted â none of these were restrictions Paula had the slightest intention of enduring for long.
label: metaphor

text: As for the House of Mattli, it might have been in a different world to the hostel, with its air of being a cross between a workhouse and a boarding school.

text: The first time she rang the bell and went in through the front doors of the elegant old house where the showrooms were situated( Mattli had no rear entrance) Paula felt she was stepping into the place of her dreams.
