text: Deep carpet covered the floors and the stairs swept up to the showrooms and the warren of workrooms beyond, and though the window drapes and furnishings were ever-so-slightly faded, as if they had seen better days, they were of the finest silks and velvets and every corner was swept, polished and cleaned daily so that no single speck of dust, let alone a cobweb, dared show itself.
label: metaphor

text: The showroom was neither large nor small, decorated in muted shades of aubergine which would not detract from the clothes.
label: metaphor

text: The crystal chandelier was for effect only â lighting that would show off the clothes to their best advantage was brilliant yet discreet, and along one wall were racks holding some of the ready-to-wear garments.

text: Pattern cutters, fitters, sewing hands and their assistants all worked at an incredible speed.
label: metaphor

text: This, Paula soon discovered, was the way of the fashion world â a constant frantic rush against the clock, to have collections ready on time or to complete individual couture garments for customers who always considered their order more urgent, more important, than that of anyone else.
label: metaphor

text: Paula was amazed by the security arrangements that were necessary to ensure that the new season's collections remained exclusive â the windows at the rear of the premises were heavily barred and practically the first thing she had to do on commencing her employment was to sign a contract promising that she would not breathe a word about the designs she saw.
label: metaphor

text: On her second day Madame Mattli took her to Vidal Sassoon's salon in Grosvenor House so that her hair could be cut in an up-to-the-minute style.

text: Unlike some couturiers Madame did not mind if her model girls did not have the same colour hair but she did insist on identical styles.

text: By the time Vidal Sassoon had finished with her Paula's long fair locks had been shorn to a sharp geometric shape and she scarcely recognised the reflection that looked back at her from the mirror.
label: metaphor

text: Among the rich and famous who had come to the salon to have their hair cut, tinted and set, Paula recognised Dusty Springfield, the pop singer, her eyes big and sooty, her lips pearly pink, and was unable to suppress the thrill of excitement which ran through her.

text: This was her very first taste of only the best being good enough â and she liked it!

text: It was Paula's job to show samples, parading slowly up and down in front of the clients as they sat on the elegant spindle-leg chairs taking in every detail of the garments with a critical and practised eye.

text: Sometimes they came alone, sometimes with a man in tow â to foot the bill!
label: metaphor

text: Paula guessed.

text: The appearance of a famous face in the show rooms always caused a stir amongst the girls, who all longed to hook a wealthy husband â and if he had a title, like the Aly Khan, or was a film star like Omar Shariff, then so much the better!

text: In the long hours when there were no customers to show she was expected to lend a hand with some of the unskilled tasks â running errands and making tea, unpicking a seam or a hem, even sewing on a button or a hook and eye when she had been taught the proper way to do it.

text: Paula was not very clever with her needle but she soon learned to be careful so as not to incur the wrath of the seamstress.

text: There were new tricks of modelling to be learned too â how to remove a coat, sliding It carefully off her shoulders with the sleeves hanging in perfect balance, never for one moment allowing the inside to be on view, for samples were often unlined.

text: This trick took hours of practice, up and down the landing at the hostel while the other girls looked at her as if she had taken leave of her senses.

text: Although she enjoyed her job Paula was lonely.

text: I like sailing alone at night.
label: metaphor

text: I like to watch the phosphorescence curling away from the hull and I like to watch the brilliant specks of light fade in the black deep water far in the ship's wake.
label: metaphor

text: I like to be alone under the careless profusion of the stars, and alone on a moon-glossed sea.
label: metaphor

text: I like the sounds of a boat sailing at night.
label: metaphor

text: The sounds are the same as those of daylight, yet somehow the night magnifies and sharpens the creak of a yielding block, the sigh of air over a shroud, the stretching of a sail, the hiss of water sliding sleek against the hull, the curl of a quarter-wave falling away, and the thump as a wave strikes the cutwater to be sheared into two bright slices of whiteness.
label: metaphor

text: I like the purposefulness of a boat at night as it slits a path across an empty planet.
label: metaphor

text: I like the secretiveness of a boat in the blackness, when the only thing to dislike is the prospect of dawn, which seems like a betrayal because, at night, in a boat under sail, it is easy to feel very close to God â for eternity is all around.
label: metaphor

text: I tacked the ship shortly after midnight, doing the job by myself and enjoying the work.

text: Explaining crime: theories of criminality
label: literal

text: Most people have their own notions or theories as to what causes criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: For example, lack of discipline in the home, genetic defects, poverty, mixing with the â wrong sort have all been proposed as causes of criminality.
label: metaphor

text: While such notions may all contains some elements of truth, they are by no means complete explanations of criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: This chapter will examine a range of theories which attempt to explain such behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: Although the major theoretical explanations are covered in the numerous introductions to the sociology of crime and deviance and to sociology generally, some review of these theories is necessary before embarking upon an examination of specific, substantive examples of criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: As this is not a book on criminological theories, what follows will be a brief overview of a wide range of theories and explanations.
label: metaphor

text: It would be naive to expect to uncover any ultimate explanation or basic cause for criminal behaviour, given the extensive and diverse behaviour that is encompassed by the term crime.
label: metaphor

text: Suppose, for example, that it could be proved that one cause of delinquency was lack of parental supervision.
label: literal

text: It might still be necessary to ask why delinquency occurred with one son or daughter but not another.
label: literal

text: Also, there would be the further question of why the parents had not provided adequate supervision.
label: literal

text: Perhaps this was because of their poor living conditions which would raise the question of why they were in poor housing.
label: metaphor

text: Clearly, we are getting further and further away from the causes of delinquent behaviour, and it is perhaps wisest to think in terms of causal processes when looking at criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: Before examining the major sociological on crime, it is useful to refer to theories from outside of sociology, from other academic disciplines.
label: metaphor

text: Thus, we will look initially at biological and psychological theories.
label: metaphor

text: Biological( or physiological) explanations are based on the notion that some individuals are predisposed to criminal behaviour because of their genetic make-up.
label: metaphor

text: The individual criminal is born so; and this is usually put down to â faulty chromosome patterns, or, more vaguely, to â hereditary traits.
label: metaphor

text: In his book L'Uomo Delinquente, Lombroso developed a complex description of what he called the â born criminal, who could be recognised by a variety of physical characteristics, in particular facial characteristics â for example large jaws and ears, and high cheek bones.
label: metaphor

text: In the medical faculty at the University of Rome there is a gallery of portraits of splendidly ugly delinquents who were used to illustrate Lombroso's theory.
label: metaphor

text: To use his own language:
label: literal

text: Thus were explained anatomically the enormous jaws, high cheek bones, prominent superciliary arches, solitary lines on the palms, extreme size of the orbits, handle-shaped or sessile ears found in criminals, savages and apes, insensibility of pain, extremely acute sight, tattooing, excessive idleness, love of orgies and the craving for evil for its own sake â¦
label: metaphor

text: These explanations see the delinquent individual as inherently more prone to criminal behaviour than the non-delinquent.
label: metaphor

text: They have been widely criticised and rejected by sociologists.
label: literal

text: Lombroso's work, for example, was based on his examination of people in prison in Italy.
label: metaphor

text: This would, necessarily, ignore the fact that many criminals do not go to prison, and that, perhaps, people in prison are not always criminal.
label: metaphor

text: Most advocates of biological theories do not express themselves in the same bizarre language and style as Lombroso, and such theories of crime are not merely historical relics that died with Lombroso.
label: metaphor

text: In a major study of institutionalised delinquents( delinquents in some form of custody) in the USA in the 1950s, Sheldon and Eleanor Glueck found that delinquent boys were twice as likely to have a mesomorphic build, a chunky, muscular, compared with non-delinquent boys.
label: metaphor

text: However, the fact that the study was restricted to institutionalised delinquents limits the validity of the association between body build and crime and delinquency.
label: metaphor

text: It may be that tougher-looking delinquents are more liable to be put away than fragile looking ones.
label: metaphor

text: Furthermore, it has been found that the association between delinquency on the one hand and height, weight and physique on the other is greatly reduced once social, background factors are taken into account.
label: metaphor

text: For example, lower working-class people are more likely to be mesomorphic as a result of their diet and continual manual labour, and this class grouping is more likely to be found represented in the criminal statistics.
label: metaphor

text: With regard to the links between criminal behaviour and inherited characteristics, there have been a number of theoretical explanations suggesting an association between criminality and particular personality characteristics.
label: metaphor

text: An example of this more sophisticated biological approach is the work of Hans Eysenck, who has argued in a series of studies, that there is a link between genetically based personality characteristics and criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: He maintains that there is a link between characteristics such as extroversion and criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: An individual's degree of extroversion or introversion is inherited, determined by his or her genetic make-up.
label: metaphor

text: The link with crime found by Eysenck was that when prisoners were tested for extroversion, more extroverts were found than in the general population.
label: metaphor

text: Eysenck then argues that extroversion is the inherited basis of criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: Extroverts take longer to learn the rules of society, they are more likely to break them, and thus more likely become convicted criminals.
label: metaphor

text: As with Lombroso's work and the Gluecks' study discussed above, by starting with institutionalised criminals, it is assumed that all prisoners are criminals and that most criminals do, in fact, go to prison.
label: metaphor

text: The people who get caught and imprisoned may not be a representative picture of all criminals.
label: metaphor

text: The major problem faced by theories suggesting a link between genetic make-up and criminal behaviour is the difficulty of distinguishing between genetic and environmental effects.
label: metaphor

text: While some genetic influence can not be ruled out, just what is inherited remains very unclear.
label: metaphor

text: These theories share certain similarities with biological explanations.
label: metaphor

text: They stress the link between criminal behaviour and specific personality traits or characteristics.
label: metaphor

text: Psychological theories, however, see these characteristics as a result of unusual or abnormal experiences, rather than as inherited.
label: metaphor

text: Thus, as with biological theories, crime is seen as pathological( a disease), as something to be looked at from the medical point of view.
label: metaphor

text: However, psychological causes are seen as treatable, whereas biological causes mark the individual for life.
label: metaphor

text: In those cases there is no possible treatment, one is born a criminal.
label: metaphor

text: Many psychological theories refer to faulty parent-child relationships, such as abnormal experiences in early childhood having a lasting effect and influence on personality.
label: metaphor

text: Studies in this area have indicated that too strict or too lax parental attitudes increase the risk of delinquency( the work of John Bowlby, for example); they have found that if a young child is deprived of close personal relationships with parents or parent figures then â problem behaviour is more common.
label: metaphor

text: It is well established that in the delinquent-prone, home discipline is more liable to be too lax, strict or erratic.
label: metaphor

text: However, it is patently obvious that parents can be a good or bad influence and example for their children, and this fact can hardly be used to explain present patterns of crime.
label: metaphor

text: The majority of offenders do not come from disturbed or broken homes, and many broken homes do not produce delinquents.
label: metaphor

text: Of course, this last point does not show that there is no link between parent-child relations and crime and delinquency.
label: metaphor

text: The problem with assessing the influence of parental and family dimensions, such as weak supervision or parental criminality, is the fact that they are closely linked to various aspects of social and economic disadvantage, such as poverty, overcrowding and poor housing.
label: metaphor

text: And it may be that these disadvantages help to cause parental difficulties, and hamper good parenting.
label: metaphor

text: We can hardly do justice to the wide scope of psychological theories here, but there are some basic ideas and assumptions which underlie such theorizing.
label: metaphor

text: These stress the importance of family relationships and upbringing during the early years, and conclude that anti-social, and by implication criminal, behaviour results from faulty personality development.
label: metaphor

text: To summarise, these biological and psychological theories hold that the criminal is a particular type of person, apart from the rest of society and with a special predisposition toward criminal behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: They are based on the idea that criminal behaviour is either inherited or a consequence of unique, individual experiences.
label: metaphor

text: Before we look at sociological explanations it might be useful to ask yourself, or to discuss with colleagues, whether you feel that criminals are different â types of person.
label: metaphor

text: While there are, no doubt, predispositions toward criminal behaviour, and clearly certain characteristics are inherited, most sociologists would reject these â individual pathology sort of theories.
label: metaphor

text: They lack convincing supporting evidence.
label: metaphor

text: While some offenders suffer from mental disorders the vast majority do not.
label: metaphor

text: Furthermore, if criminals are abnormal then it follows that a large proportion of the population must also be abnormal.
label: metaphor

text: For numerous studies have shown that a high percentage of the population have committed criminal offences, in particular high proportions of juveniles, and it is difficult to believe that they are all different or abnormal.
label: metaphor

text: We said above that sociologists would reject non-sociological explanations of crime.
label: metaphor

text: In Chapter One, it was stressed that crime can not be considered aside from its social context, that it is dependent on society defining certain actions as criminal, and on the reaction of others to such actions.
label: metaphor

text: A Model to Link Personality Characteristics to a Preference for Science
label: metaphor

text: In recent years there has been a steady accumulation of evidence that personality and allied affective factors play a crucial role in determining subject choice and student success.
label: metaphor

text: Unfortunately, this evidence has tended to be fragmentary, a collection of separate, discrete pieces of information lacking a synthesizing theory to provide cohesion and predictive power.
label: metaphor

text: The few models which have been developed to date may have been correct as far as they go but are clearly incomplete.
label: metaphor

text: For example Roe( 1952), Eiduson( 1962) and McClelland( 1962) suggested that male scientists often experienced a lonely childhood, perhaps suffering social isolation through illness or family circumstances, so that they developed a strong interest in their surrounding material world and a below average interest in other people and relationships.
label: metaphor

text: Maslow( 1966) and Hudson( 1966 and 1968) saw science as providing an emotionally undemanding activity appealing to boys moving from the calm of latency to the turbulence of adolescence.
label: metaphor

text: Even if these descriptions are valid they still leave open a number of questions, particularly why the same mechanisms do not operate with girls.
label: metaphor

text: Arising from the evidence in the literature and from our empirical studies at Chelsea College it is now possible to offer a model which is compatible with all the evidence and which also has considerable predictive potential.
label: metaphor

text: What we know about persons choosing science
label: metaphor

text: The evidence for an association between personality characteristics and an interest in science has been more fully reviewed by Head( 1979).
label: metaphor

text: We need now only take note of the most salient features.
label: metaphor

text: The predominance of males, particularly in the physical sciences and engineering, throughout the Western world can no longer be satisfactorily attributed to cognitive differences, which are too small, nor to institutional factors.
label: metaphor

text: Equal opportunity in education and employment has not made science any more popular with women.
label: metaphor

text: Furthermore, the characteristics of those students who do opt for science show clear sex differences.
label: metaphor

text: Male scientists, both science students and mature, professional scientists, tend to be emotionally reticent, disliking overt emotional expression in others and themselves, and depending upon their partners in personal relationships to take the emotional initiatives.
label: metaphor

text: They will also tend to be authoritarian, conservative and controlled in their thinking.
label: metaphor

text: These differences can be seen quite early on; we have found boys aged 14 years who were opting for science to be significantly more authoritarian than their peers.
label: metaphor

text: Girls choosing science are not particularly emotionally reticent or rigid in their thinking, although they do seem to have low self-esteem in terms of being socially and sexually attractive.
label: metaphor

text: We also know that at about the age of 13 a very high proportion of boys are attracted to science and scientific careers.
label: metaphor

text: Thereafter, there is a steady decline of interest in science and this disillusionment extends right through the secondary-school years and into the undergraduate period.
label: metaphor

text: In contrast, only a minority of girls express an interest in science at any age but there is no obvious swing from science in the middle and late teens.
label: metaphor

text: Some further evidence has come from our use of sentence completion tests with secondary-school pupils as part of our research programme at Chelsea.
label: metaphor

text: Analysis of these responses provides further information on sex differences and between those opting for different subjects.
label: metaphor

text: For example, girls at the age of 12 and 14 years seem to take a more mature attitude to personal relationships, seeing their complexity and reciprocal nature, while boys are more exploitative.
label: metaphor

text: In relation to the sentence stem â A girl and her mother â¦, girls often produce responses like â often go through a bad patch for a year but once they learn to understand each other, become the best of friends or â can help each other with their problems.
label: metaphor

text: Similar questions, when asked of boys, tend to produce banal responses or exploitative ones, for example the parent is seen as the source of money.
label: metaphor

text: In contrast, boys seem to have a firmer self-identity and a clearer ambition showing more insight in response to sentence stems such as â My main problem is â¦ and â He/she felt proud that â¦.
label: metaphor

text: Such findings give us some clues about the characteristics of boys and girls of these ages.
label: metaphor

text: If we compare boys of 14 years of age who opt for science with other boys, we find that the former have very cut-and-dried views on many issues.
label: metaphor

text: For example, they take the view that â criminals should be severely punished or that â anyone who is unpopular deserves his fate.
label: metaphor

text: To the sentence stem â When a child will not join in group activities â¦, these boys gave responses like â he is selfish, â he must be stupid, â he deserves to be unpopular.
label: metaphor

text: In contrast, other boys and most girls pondered the possible causes and ways of integrating the child into the group.
label: metaphor

text: The science boys seemed to possess few doubts or uncertainties, they offered clear-cut answers.
label: metaphor

text: It was this evidence which suggested the possible model for subject choice in terms of ego-identity achievement.
label: metaphor

text: This model was originally postulated by Erikson( 1965) and then developed by Marcia( 1966 and 1976).
label: metaphor

text: Erikson suggests that at different phases of life an individual faces a particular psycho-social problem which needs to be resolved before moving on to the next phase.
label: metaphor

text: By the end of adolescence he or she needs to make choices about career, life-style, personal relationships and ideologies.
label: metaphor

text: The ego-identity of that person is shaped by these choices.
label: metaphor

text: Erikson does not suggest that the development of an ego-identity is a once-and-for-all issue.
label: literal

text: Some problems about identity arise with the young child in the context of home and school, and others occur in later life, for example on retirement.
label: metaphor

text: Nevertheless, adolescence is the time when ego-identity development inevitably dominates the personal development of the individual for a while.
label: metaphor

text: The adolescent does not, however, need to achieve a clear ego-identity on all topics at one time.
label: metaphor

text: In this article we are concerned with ego-identity achievement in respect to career.
label: metaphor

text: Marcia has put more detail onto the Erikson model and suggests that in going from the initial ego-diffusion condition to that of having achieved ego-identity, two processes are involved: crisis and commitment.
label: metaphor

text: Crisis in this context describes a period of intensive self-examination in which one's beliefs and values are re-examined.
label: metaphor

text: Commitment means that the individual has acquired clear and firm beliefs both about himself or herself and the world.
label: metaphor

text: Figure 16.1 indicates a number of possible routes to ego-identity achievements.
label: metaphor

text: A person may undergo crisis and commitment simultaneously and progress by route A. An alternative is to undergo a period of considerable self-doubt and self-examination in which all one's beliefs tend to be very fluid, a period known as moratorium, before acquiring beliefs for oneself and ego-identity is achieved( route B).
label: metaphor

text: A further possibility is that the individual may, at least for a time, hold onto beliefs and values taken without question from others, for example parents, teachers, peers.
label: metaphor

text: This condition is known as foreclosure.
label: metaphor

text: Eventually these persons might have to face up to period of crisis, of self-examination, and so achieve ego-identity by route C. However, foreclosure does offer an escape route and an individual might postpone indefinitely any real self-examination by clinging rigidly to his or her beliefs and values( route D).
label: metaphor

text: We can now make the link between this model of adolescent development and subject choice in schools.
label: metaphor

text: The physical sciences in particular, offer a conventional career choice which is likely to win approval from parents, teachers and peers.
label: metaphor

text: They will tend to regard the overt expression of emotions, including much such expression in the arts, as being soft and feminine.
label: metaphor

text: Science, with its masculine image, makes little emotional demand on an individual and seems to offer clear, precise answers to problems.
label: metaphor

text: Opting for science will permit and possibly reinforce emotional reticence.
label: metaphor

text: There is evidence that girls tend to be socialized into adult roles more through their potential of becoming a mother and housewife than through their career( Douvan and Adelson, 1966).
label: metaphor

text: Furthermore, these girls will tend to go into a career with a feminine image, one which already attracts many girls.
label: metaphor

text: Consequently, very few girls at the foreclosure stage will enter science unless they receive considerable encouragement and a model to do so from their parents and their school.
label: metaphor

text: Neither boys nor girls at the moratorium stage are likely to be attracted to the science that is usually presented in our schools.
label: metaphor

text: They are at a stage when they are likely to be concerned with a variety of complex issues; the meaning of life, the existence of God, ideologies, their emerging sexuality, their future career and life-style â too often science is seen as being purely instrumental with nothing to contribute to these debates.
label: metaphor

text: Science, somehow, seems to be scarcely relevant to the most important issues in our life.
label: metaphor

text: A proportion of both boys and girls at ego-identity achievement stage will choose science.
label: metaphor

text: In fact, most girls entering science are probably at this stage as they will need some self-examination and sense of commitment to make this unconventional choice.
label: metaphor

text: However, only a minority of adolescents will have reached the ego-identity achievement stage at the age when most pupils have to make crucial decisions about subject choice at school.
label: metaphor

text: This model seems to explain our observations.
label: metaphor

text: A large number of boys, particularly at the foreclosure stage, are initially attracted to science but there is a drift away throughout later adolescence as they undergo some crisis.
label: metaphor

text: The preponderance of boys at the foreclosure stage will yield the rigid, authoritarian attitudes often associated with scientists.
label: metaphor

text: The few girls who enter science will not usually show these foreclosure characteristics.

text: The real use of this model linking personality development to subject choice is that it allows us to make predictions about how pupils might react to changes in school science curriculum and school organization.
label: metaphor

text: We can consider three possible changes:
label: metaphor

text: Delaying subject choice: Britain is unusual in asking pupils to make crucial choices about subject options in the 13â16 age range.
label: metaphor

text: These decisions can only be reversed with great difficulty.
label: metaphor

text: What effect would delaying the choice make?
label: metaphor

text: In the development through the years of adolescence the number of foreclosure pupils will diminish, hence the recruitment of boys into science would be cut.
label: metaphor

text: More boys and girls will have reached the ego-identity achievement stage and a proportion of these will go into science.
label: metaphor

text: Overall there would be a reduction in the number of students choosing science, but those who do so choose will be more likely to stay happily in the subject and to possess more flexible minds.
label: metaphor

text: The quantitative loss would be met by a qualitative improvement.
label: metaphor

text: Giving science a more feminine image: It is sometimes argued that science textbooks are sexist in showing illustrations of boys, rather than girls, doing practical work in the laboratory, and so forth.
label: metaphor

text: What effect would a deliberate attempt to change this image have?
label: metaphor

text: It might make it easier for girls at the foreclosure stage to accept science so recruitment might increase.
label: metaphor

text: Some of these girls might, however, drift away again when they reach their crisis period.
label: metaphor

text: Unless the change in image was immense, boys would probably not be affected, science would still be an obvious, acceptable choice for a boy.
label: metaphor

text: Emphasizing the applications and relevance of science: To obtain a major qualitative improvement to recruitment in science with more girls and with students possessing imaginative, flexible minds it would be necessary to make science appealing to boys and girls at the moratorium stage.
label: metaphor

text: In that event science must be seen to be relevant to the issues which concern them.
label: metaphor

text: The probable implication is that science would need to be presented in the context of the needs of society and individuals.
label: metaphor

text: Probably a case-study approach involving the application of science, and the interaction with other disciplines, would be needed.
label: metaphor

text: Our knowledge about the girls' concern with personal relationships suggests that the introduction of some elements of the social sciences into the case studies might prove attractive.

text: Is it possible to change school science in this fashion and still preserve the essential character of science itself?
label: metaphor

text: Clearly there would need to be some drastic pruning of content.

text: Perhaps science teachers should not attempt to cover their subjects so comprehensively.
label: metaphor

text: A history teacher is content to cover the history of one country or continent over a few decades.
label: metaphor

text: Perhaps we must make similar choices.

text: It is interesting to notice that the Association for Science Education( 1979) policy statement in Britain and the proposals on school physics coming from the Institute for Science Education( IPN) in Kiel are advocating such changes.
label: metaphor

text: The difference is that we are now offering a formal psychological model to suggest that if we want to reduce the current encapsulation of science, if we want to recruit a different sort of student, then certain curriculum changes are needed.

text: Approximately three times as many boys as girls take O level physics and approximately four times as many take CSE physics.

text: This means that schoolgirls are ineligible for a wide range of courses in further and higher education and for entry to occupations requiring a scientific or technical base.

text: Female exclusion from science and technology, even if it is apparently by girls' own choice, also means that as citizens their ability to understand and control their environment is limited.

text: Girls Into Science and Technology( GIST) was the first major schools-based project addressing problems of sex stereotyping at school, and was an example of â action research in education; the project simultaneously took action to improve girls' achievement in science and technology and investigated the reasons for their under-achievement.
label: metaphor

text: The project team collaborated with teachers in eight co-educational comprehensive schools in the Greater Manchester area to devise and implement intervention strategies designed to improve girls' attitudes to the physical sciences and technical subjects.
label: metaphor

text: Two other schools were involved as controls where attitude testing but no interventions took place. â¦
label: metaphor

text: The approach was collaborative: teachers were invited to work with the team as equal partners in the attempts both to investigate and find solutions to the GIST problem.
label: metaphor

text: However, very few of the teachers even recognized the issue as one of professional concern at the start of the project, and most of the first two years was spent in establishing the educational importance of the issue and working towards the development of feasible intervention strategies.
label: metaphor

text: The project and its outcomes have been fully described elsewhere( Smail et al.,
label: metaphor

text: GIST had more success in altering children's attitudes than their subject choices, suggesting that it is easier to change attitudes and beliefs than actual behaviour.
label: metaphor

text: Pupils in action schools became markedly less stereotyped than pupils in control schools.
label: metaphor

text: They also had slightly more positive attitudes towards science and scientists and were less likely to define them as exclusively masculine.
label: metaphor

text: Despite some evidence of change in teachers' attitudes and behaviour, they themselves were reluctant to admit that the project had influenced them.
label: metaphor

text: According to an evaluation report this may reflect an unwillingness to admit that in the past schools have been sex biased( Payne, Cuff and Hustler, 1984).
label: metaphor

text: The GIST hypothesis was that female under-achievement in science and technology is at least partly socially constructed by the school, an hypothesis based on research evidence as well as critical feminist analysis( see, for example, Kelly, 1981).
label: metaphor

text: During the project there was a shift away from locating the issue as one of girls' motivation towards attempts to change the nature of school science.
label: metaphor

text: One of the main gains from the GIST project has been the clarification of what is meant by a â girl friendly, science, that is a science which will appeal equally to the interests and concerns of girls as well as boys. â¦
label: metaphor

text: Several interventions were designed to make science more girl friendly.
label: metaphor

text: Schools and teachers tried curriculum development to build on girls' science interests, changing patterns of classroom interaction, single sex groups and classes.
label: metaphor

text: The largest scale intervention was the VISTA programme, which consisted of women scientists and technologists visiting schools to talk to children about an aspect of their jobs already being covered in the school science syllabus.
label: metaphor

text: VISTA made science more girl friendly in two ways: both boys and girls were offered an attractive image of a competent woman scientist, and talks concentrated on social and industrial applications of science, an element too often missing from science at school.
label: metaphor

text: One school was so impressed by the children's positive reactions that they completely revamped the science work in the first two years to include more social and human applications of science.
label: metaphor

text: The survey of children's attitudes helped here: research such as Ormerod's( 1971; Ormerod and Duckworth, 1975) had shown that girls were interested in the social implications of science, but did not tell teachers what the desirable teaching approach might be in practice.
label: metaphor

text: A question from our survey asked children whether they would like to know more about how a vacuum cleaner works; hardly anyone did, and girls were even less curious than boys.
label: metaphor

text: This told us that any simplistic assumptions about featuring â female domestic interests in science would probably meet with failure.
label: metaphor

text: The rest of the questionnaire about science curiosity showed that all the children were enthusiastic about learning science, and that girls were keen to know more about nature, the environment and medical science.
label: metaphor

text: Over 50 per cent, and in some cases over 60 per cent said they would like to learn about the human heart, germs and illnesses, how our muscles work, what food is good for you, life in the sea, what makes a rainbow appear and how a record is made.
label: metaphor

text: At present the science curriculum is structured around physical science interests, on which boys are keener( how motor cars work, atoms and molecules); we were able to recommend that teaching build on the overlapping interests of the two sexes, because girls as well as boys want to know more about human biology and spectacular features of the environment( animals in the jungle, volcanoes and earthquakes, acids and chemicals).
label: metaphor

text: The less immediately attractive parts of science could be approached through these interests, for instance teaching â forces by beginning with the action of muscles in the human arm, and â light via the dissection of a bull's eye.
label: metaphor

text: When women scientists employ such approaches, and describe their own work, as happened during the VISTA programme, girls are receiving double encouragement.
label: metaphor

text: These examples indicate some of the features of girl friendly science: it builds on girls' interests, not just boys'; it explicitly encourages girls to see themselves as potential scientists, and it includes some of the social and human implications and applications of science.
label: metaphor

text: All the GIST schools were mixed comprehensives, and at first teachers were most unwilling to separate boys and girls at all, on the grounds that it ran counter to their co-educational comprehensive philosophy.
label: metaphor

text: Then certain teachers were particularly struck by the evidence of large differences in the interests and experience children brought with them to school.
label: metaphor

text: Girls had far less â tinkering experience than boys and the connection with their lesser interest in topics like â how electricity is produced seemed obvious.
label: metaphor

text: Several special science or craft clubs were organized in the lunch hour for girls only and in two schools teachers planned single-sex teaching.
label: metaphor

text: As we shall see, it was in these two schools that the largest measurable changes of attitude and option choice occurred.
label: metaphor

text: For a more girl friendly science, it seems vital that teachers should come to see that when all the masculine packaging, evident in textbooks and resources as well as teachers' and boys' behaviour in the classroom, is removed, girls can be very enthusiastic about science. â¦
label: metaphor

text: Alison Kelly sees at least four distinct senses in which it can be argued that science is masculine.
label: metaphor

text: First, the pupils, teachers and practitioners of science are overwhelmingly male in terms of numbers; second, school science is packaged and presented to appeal to boys, not girls; third, classroom behaviours and interaction operate to reconstruct science as a male activity, and finally it has been suggested that â scientific thinking embodies an intrinsically masculine world view.
label: metaphor

text: The GIST interventions described above relate to three of these: VISTA women, albeit briefly and temporarily, redressed the numerical balance by offering female role models of practising scientists; VISTA and the curriculum development which followed involved a limited â repackaging of science to remove its exclusively masculine appeal, and the single-sex classes and classroom observation showed how science comes to be defined as â masculine in the mixed school.
label: metaphor

text: The fourth point, the idea that science is intrinsically masculine, can be sustained only by clinging to an irredeemably narrow conception of science and scientific thinking.
label: metaphor

text: Girls are not uninterested in science, they are bored by the limited version of it they meet in school.
label: metaphor

text: One of the purposes of an extended period of single-sex science teaching might be to let teachers see how girls approach scientific matters, and to discover, what may well be the case, that girls are just as capable of â scientific thinking as boys.
label: metaphor

text: Margaret Spear, in a different study from the one reported in this volume, found that for identical work boys were marked higher than girls for supposed understanding of principles, aptitude for science and O level suitability( Spear, 1984).
label: metaphor

text: Over against the German army or the Vichy government, where social generality ruled, as it does in all machines of state, the Resistance offered the rare phenomenon of historical action which remained personal.
label: metaphor

text: The psychological and moral elements of political action were almost the only ones to appear here, which is why intellectuals least inclined to politics were to be seen in the Resistance.
label: metaphor

text: The Resistance was a unique experience for them, and they wanted to preserve its experience in the new French politics because this experience broke away from the famous dilemma of being and doing, which confronts all intellectuals in the face of action â¦.
label: metaphor

text: It is only too obvious that this balance between action and personal life was intimately bound up with the conditions of clandestine action and could not survive it.
label: metaphor

text: And in this sense it must be said that the Resistance experience, by making us believe that politics is a relationship between man and man or between consciousnesses, fostered our illusions of 1939 and masked the truth of the incredible power of history which the Occupation taught us in another connection.
label: metaphor

text: If by 1945 Merleau-ponty had here already indicated the historical basis for what was to become Sartre's project in the Critique, the theoretical problem that followed was how to unite orthodox Marxist concepts of economic determinism and historical necessity with the individualism of Sartre's earlier work, that is the existentialist notion of the authentic self and the possibility of choosing one's own freedom: how to relocate human practice within historical determinism, to reconcile the individual with the social, the idea of agency with that of necessity, or freedom with history?
label: metaphor

text: Citing Marx's famous remark in The Eighteenth Brumaire, â Men make their own History â¦ but under circumstances â¦ given and transmitted from the past, Sartre suggested that this implied â the permanent and dialectical unity of freedom and necessity,( I, 35).
label: metaphor

text: Accordingly, he attempted to shift Marxism away from orthodox theories of an absolute determinism towards the primacy of a concept of â History which, while still a totality as it had been for Luk¡cs, a process with a determinate meaning and end, could also include a concept of human agency and thus articulate the individual with the social, freedom with determinism.
label: metaphor

text: Today, Sartre's voluntarism is to some extent returning to favour as the result of a desire to retrieve the categories of agency and the subject, which goes together with the wish to get out of the apparently totalizing systems of Adorno, Althusser or Foucault.
label: metaphor

text: Sartre's stress on the role of the subject also finds approval because many of those no longer prepared to argue for a general theory of history as the progress of a single narrative of class-struggle, have begun to argue instead for a return of its correlative, the subject, almost as if it was the next best thing in the absence of history itself.
label: metaphor

text: But it still leaves us with the crucial problem that Sartre had to solve, namely how to link human consciousness with the processes of history so that the former can be said to be the agent of the latter.
label: metaphor

text: How could this take place?
label: metaphor

text: As Sartre had put it in What is Literature?:
label: metaphor

text: â Never has homo faber better understood that he has made history and never has he felt so powerless before history.
label: metaphor

text: How can man make history if at the same time it is history which makes him?
label: metaphor

text: Sartre considered that orthodox dialectical materialism takes the easy way out by merely eliminating the first in favour of the second, making man a passive product entirely determined by economic circumstances.
label: metaphor

text: Unwilling to follow Merleau-Ponty by dropping the second in favour of the first, Sartre argued that it was possible for man to be both at once through the movement of praxis, that is intentional actions which produce material effects.
label: metaphor

text: Its corollary, whereby praxis becomes determining history, he called the â practico-inert, by which he meant the material circumstances that have themselves been created by previous praxes and which form the conditions for new praxis.
label: metaphor

text: The individual is thus both totalizer and totalized, deftly uniting freedom with necessity.
label: metaphor

text: Though this neatly solves the problem of how man can make history while at the same time history makes him, it does not answer the larger question of how a multiplicity of the products of individual acts, â totalizations, can themselves be totalized into the overall totalization required by the logic of dialectical rationality â rather than being the arbitrary, blind and self-cancelling movements of, say, Hardy's immanent will.
label: metaphor

text: Sartre's fundamental thesis, that â History continually effects totalisations of totalisations( I, 15), does not in itself answer what Ronald Aronson has rightly characterized as the question for Sartre: â how do separate, antagonistic actions yield a history; how do individual totalizations lead to Totalization( and also progress, the direction of history, its truth and its meaning)?
label: metaphor

text: For the whole basis of Sartre's argument is that the dialectic of history is not a metaphysical law, â some powerful unitary force revealing itself behind History like the will of God, but the continuously produced effect of individual conflicts; each action is in its turn subsumed as a part of the whole in an ever broader, developing totalization( I, 37).
label: metaphor

text: What Sartre needs to demonstrate, therefore, is that if the law of the dialectic works from the individual level, overall it produces nothing less than the intelligibility or the meaning of History as such:
label: metaphor

text: The dialectic is the law of totalization which creates several collectivities, several societies, and one history â realities, that is, which impose themselves on individuals; but at the same time it must be woven out of millions of individual actions.
label: metaphor

text: We must show that it is possible for it to be both a resultant â¦ and a totalizing force â¦ how it can continually bring about the unity of dispersive profusion and integration.
label: metaphor

text: But what produces the overall direction of History?
label: metaphor

text: How does it â continually bring about the unity of dispersive profusion and integration?
label: literal

text: Sartre does not attempt to answer this question, shifting rather to the notion of a lack of self-consciousness.
label: metaphor

text: The dialectic is the law that remains hidden.
label: metaphor

text: At the moment, â history is made without being known( l'histoire se fait sans se connitre) â history constitutes, we might say today, a political unconscious.
label: metaphor

text: â Marxism, on the other hand, Sartre claims, â is History itself becoming conscious of itself( I, 40): as for Luk¡cs, it is by becoming conscious of itself as the subject of history that the working class will understand history's meaning â and so recognize itself as the meaning of history.
label: metaphor

text: While he suggests in apocalyptic tones in The Problem of Method that this process of self-consciousness is at last beginning to take place, and that civil, foreign and colonial wars are becoming apparent as different forms of a single class struggle, Sartre also admits that the divorce between theory and praxis which ensued under Stalinism has generally prevented any clear self-consciousness among the masses.
label: metaphor

text: The â detour, of Stalinism is thus formalized as Marxism's own descent into its unconscious, resulting in a dream-work of heterogeneous histories that have eluded systematization and subsumption into the single meaning of Marxism's own reading of history.
label: metaphor

text: It is therefore, Sartre argues, our historical task to make it known, promoting not just the historical process as such, but also the general recognition whereby the plurality of the meanings of individual histories can be seen to combine to make one history, with one meaning â the â Truth of humanity( I, 822).
label: metaphor

text: Sartre's account thus sets up the articulation of history, univocal meaning, and totality as the indissoluble set of elements required for the validation of Marxism, necessary in order to save it from its detour from itself.
label: metaphor

text: The problem, however, remains how such universals are produced from the multiplicity of initiating individual praxes.
label: metaphor

text: If History is a history of conflict, how could it be both one and internally diversified without the inner moving principle of the dialectic?
label: metaphor

text: How can History be a unity if it is also conflictual, if each action is aimed at destroying the other and results in a double negation in which the original aims of each action have been destroyed by the other?
label: metaphor

text: If each action negates the aim of the other, where is the â unity totalized in the conflict?
label: metaphor

text: How does History constantly totalize itself?
label: literal

text: ( I, 817 â 18) Sartre arrives at what he calls â the real problem of History, that is how there can be totalization without a totalizer, only at the very end of Volume I. It is not until the next volume, however, that he intends to show how individual actions, separate multiplicities, make up â one human history, with one truth and one intelligibility( I, 69).
label: metaphor

text: Throughout, Sartre has nevertheless taken it â for granted that such a totalisation is constantly developing both as History and as historical Truth( I, 822).
label: metaphor

text: His History, therefore, is always in process: but its teleology of a final totalization always has to be assumed.
label: metaphor

text: He thus asserts the Truth of History while constantly projecting forwards and deferring its proof.
label: metaphor

text: But when the proof comes it also turns out to rest on the assumption that it is already true.
label: metaphor

text: â We are trying to establish the Truth of History'
label: literal

text: Sartre produces a persuasive formulation of the relation of the individual to the determining historical circumstance through his concepts of praxis and the practico-inert; it is also obvious to him how the larger question of History ought to be solved.
label: metaphor

text: He asserts it often enough: â History continually effects totalisations of totalisations,( I, 15).
label: literal

text: But in Volume I of the Critique, as we have seen, he continually defers the demonstration of his proof.
label: metaphor

text: For the â dogmatic dialectic, as he describes dialectical materialism, the whole question naturally poses no problem, for each person or group simply constitutes a partial moment of an already operative movement of totalization that produces them and then goes beyond them.
label: metaphor

text: But Sartre's dispensing with all historicist schemas creates the problem of how, between two autonomous and contradictory totalizations, there could be â one dialectical intelligibility of the ongoing process( II, 13).
label: metaphor

text: He attempts to solve this through matching his account of contradiction with a new concept derived from the conjunction of work and labour: â anti-labour( anti-travail), a category of negation.
label: metaphor

text: The products of a conflict, as well as its residues, may seem incomprehensible insofar as they differ from the original intentions of any of the combatants.
label: metaphor

text: Nevertheless they constitute the basis and conditions for further actions and history.
label: literal

text: Dialectical reason encounters such products as undecidables:
label: metaphor

text: aporias â because they seem to be at once the results of a communal enterprise while at the same time bearing witness to the fact that this enterprise never existed except as the inhuman reverse side of two opposed actions in which each aims to destroy the other.
label: metaphor

text: In the dialectical perspective, we encounter these objects as productions which are human and provided with a future â¦ thus they seem by themselves to be totalizations in process.
label: metaphor

text: This means that first, they lead to results, and second, that the internal structure of social objects contains â the double negation of themselves and of each constituent part by the other( II, 22).
label: metaphor

text: There is, therefore, before any understanding of historic agents and movements, a certain aporia in all social ensembles: from afar they may appear whole, but close to, they can be seen as riddled with holes.
label: metaphor

text: This increasingly comes to resemble nothing so much as Sartre's own account of History.
label: metaphor

text: In the context of the negativity of this formulation, Sartre is obliged to pose once again the problem of whether there can be a totalization, without any independent totalizer or totalizing force such as the dialectic, or whether the structure of negation that he has described means that, as for Adorno or Bakhtin, history does not develop positively but, rather, negatively, and is therefore instead detotalizing:
label: metaphor

text: Marxism is rigorously true if History is totalization; it is not so any more if human history decomposes into a plurality of particular histories, or if, in any case, within the relationship of immanence that characterizes struggle, the negation of each adversary by the other is on principle detotalizing.
label: metaphor

text: Certainly, we have neither the design nor the actual possibility of showing here the full truth of dialectical materialism â¦
label: metaphor

text: Our goal is solely to establish whether, in a practical ensemble torn apart by antagonism( whether there are multiple conflicts or whether they are reduced to one) the breaks themselves are totalizing and carried along by the totalizing movement of the ensemble.
label: metaphor

text: At this point Sartre confronts the possibility that the whole project of the Critique, stated so confidently on its very first page â â it must be proved that a negation of a negation can be an affirmation( I, 15) â may break down.
label: metaphor

text: perhaps the Truth of History can not be proved; its direction can not be discerned.
label: metaphor

text: Sartre's reaction to the threat that the negation of a negation may produce a detotalizing effect is to introduce a new category, a unifying force of a â singularization which incarnates the universal: â If totalization really is an ongoing process, he writes, â then it operates everywhere.
label: metaphor

text: That means both that there is a dialectical meaning of the practical ensemble â¦ and that each singular event totalizes in itself the practical ensemble in the infinite richness of its singularity( II, 26).
label: metaphor

text: Unlike Luk¡cs' insignificant event from which the universal is precariously drawn out through the narrative, Sartre's singularity works synecdochally in a conventional antinomy with the universal, the relation between the two structured according to the familiar nineteenth-century model of organic growth or process in which each singular event makes up the whole while, as he puts it, â the whole is entirely present in the part as its present meaning and as its destiny.
label: metaphor

text: Sartre's â singular universal, therefore, begs the question, for it is predicated on the assumption that, if there is not a totality as such, then there already is an overall totalization: â If totalization really is an ongoing process â¦.
label: metaphor

text: That developing process is itself totalized through Sartre's assertion that each totalization is the totalization of all struggles, as it must be if the singular is to incarnate the universal.
label: metaphor

text: The concept of the singular universal thus facilitates a circularity in the argument whereby Sartre can avoid the question which he began by posing.
label: metaphor

text: So the singular universal presumes the totalization he can't( yet) prove.
label: metaphor

text: This strategy marks a structure of repetition in Sartre's text: each time he poses the question of how there can be totalization of History without a totalizer, he retreats to a more limited example whose unity is already evident, but which in the end only brings him back to the original question again.
label: metaphor

text: In this case Sartre demonstrates how the singular universal works, by appealing to the concrete example of a boxing match â a random exemplification that just happens to reproduce the single adversaries of the master/slave dialectic.
label: metaphor

text: Its totalization takes place through its incarnation, as part of the totality of boxing, in the overall framework within which each individual fight occurs.
label: metaphor

text: Each boxing match, Sartre claims, must be both a unique event and also in some sense the incarnation of all boxing, whose rules and conventions it follows, and whose past and future history it sets itself against.
label: metaphor

text: But it is also apparent that that totality is not completely known, nor is its future shape even presumed.
label: metaphor

text: By totalization, therefore, Sartre does not here mean anything like a predetermined end or final closure of a totality but rather a process of mediation among the parts, where each is determined by the other.
label: metaphor

text: No one can predict the future of boxing, either at the level of particular victories or defeats, in effect a structure of repetition, nor at the more general level of possible modifications or developments of the sport.
label: metaphor

text: Yet each individual bout articulates itself within the framework of the history of boxing, known and unknown.
label: metaphor

text: This allows Sartre to include chance and contingency in his scheme.
label: metaphor

text: Since it can not be known as a concept that will realize itself in the future, Sartre argues instead that the totality only produces itself in the moment: â The incarnation as such is at once unrealizable except as totalization of everything and irreducible to a pure abstract unity of that which it totalizes( II, 58).
label: metaphor

text: The universal, the totality, can only be known through the singular.
label: metaphor

text: But its future direction remains unknown and indeterminate.
label: metaphor

text: At the same time Sartre makes a larger, though less persuasive claim that the boxing-match also works synecdochally and re-exteriorizes a more fundamental violence, namely the interiorized condition of scarcity that he considers to be the basis of conflict in general.
label: metaphor

text: The boxing match â is the public incarnation of all conflict( II, 32), totalizing in its own struggle the whole of â contemporary irreducibilities and fissures( II, 26):
label: metaphor

text: thus one can and must say â¦ that each fight is the singularisation of all the circumstances of the social whole in movement and that by this singularisation, it incarnates the enveloping totalization which the historical process is.
label: metaphor

text: But then he adds, â I have said and I repeat that we have not yet proved that this enveloping totalization exists.
label: metaphor

text: So, although it is possible to conceive of any event as an incarnation of the totality, insofar as it must itself make up a part of that totality in its determination, unlike the case of the boxing match, where we can define the overall entity â boxing, it still remains unproven that an overall entity, â History, can be said to exist at all.
label: metaphor

text: For all his use of the model of the boxing match, Sartre has really got no further with the fundamental question of how there can be totalization without a totalizer.
label: metaphor

text: It is simple enough for him to show that a boxing match takes place within a general totality of â boxing, which is itself only ever present in any individual incarnation, for as a game each match is both an individual bout and something conducted according to general rules and a specific social tradition.
label: metaphor

text: But what about those conflicts that do not take place within such a constituted social system, such as conflictual bourgeois societies which can not be said to be unified, except, as Sartre suggests dismissively, by appeal to a lost paradise before the class struggle?
label: metaphor

text: Such societies make the conflicts of history irreducible to Sartre's logic unless, like the boxing match, they can be shown to take part in a larger totalizable category.
label: metaphor

text: However, when he poses the question of whether his method could work as well for the class struggle as for the boxing match, Sartre admits that he finds it impossible to answer and returns instead to the much easier case of sub-groups.
label: metaphor

text: Once again he backtracks and assumes a larger unity in which conflict takes place.
label: metaphor

text: The major question thus always remains unanswered in the Critique: every time that Sartre announces that he is about to proceed with the fundamental problem of how History can be a totalization without a totalizer, he turns back to a previous, more easily intelligible stage on the way.
label: metaphor

text: His difficulty is accompanied by a no doubt symptomatic increasing distrust of universals so that, in championing specificities against them, he seems to give up the attempt to validate the universals â History as Totalization â that originally formed the object of his project.
label: metaphor

text: Design : Crossed lines over the toytown tram : City transport could soon be back on the right track , says Jonathan Glancey
label: metaphor

text: By JONATHAN GLANCEY
label: literal

text: MODERN trams , as most continental Europeans know , neither shake nor rattle , nor do they roll .
label: literal

text: Sleek , solidly built , gentle on the environment , they are often an ideal form of city transport .
label: metaphor

text: They also exert a fascination very much of their own as they slither round circuses and brush through old city gates , flashing arcs of lightning as they switch tracks on winter nights .
label: metaphor

text: Single-car , articulated or double-decker , trams are one of the most reliable and enduring forms of public transport invented .
label: metaphor

text: The orange-liveried ‘ 1500 ’ series trams in Milan , for example , date from 1927 .
label: literal

text: Eventually they will be replaced , but more than 60 years on they run with the rhythmic reliability of a Swiss watch .
label: metaphor

text: They are as much a part of Milan as La Scala or the Galleria Vittore Emmanuele .
label: literal

text: Last month it was announced that Britain will get its first new-wave trams in 1991 .
label: metaphor

text: Destined to run in Manchester , they will relieve traffic congestion and help to reduce the levels of carbon monoxide in the city centre , outlying suburbs and satellite towns of Bury , Altrincham , Salford , Oldham and Rochdale .
label: metaphor

text: In Britain , with the main exception of Blackpool ( not forgetting the single-deckers of the Isle of Man and Llandudno ) , trams had been largely relegated to the history books .
label: literal

text: Otherwise , the best place to see working trams has been the tram museum at Crich in Derbyshire or else in old British Transport Commission films and Ealing comedies .
label: metaphor

text: Trams disappeared from most British cities in the 1950s .
label: literal

text: London 's venerable red and cream double-deckers rumbled along the Thames embankment for the last time in 1952 .
label: metaphor

text: Somehow the image of the tall , thin , mournful double-deck tram with its wooden body , slatted wooden seats and growling electric motor has stuck in the British mind .
label: metaphor

text: Trams , it was believed until surprisingly recently , are old-fashioned .
label: literal

text: They had something to do with fish and chips wrapped in newspaper , men in hats , National Health specs , smog and powdered egg .
label: literal

text: They held up the bright new diesel buses and , even worse , blocked the progress of private motorists in bulbous Austins and lumpen Humbers in canyon-like city thoroughfares .
label: metaphor

text: They picked up power from a spider 's web of unsightly overhead wires .
label: metaphor

text: They were inflexible in operation , draughty , and mobile reminders of TB epidemics with the enamelled ‘ Do Not Spit ’ signs screwed to their bulkheads .
label: metaphor

text: But the modern tram could hardly be more different .
label: literal

text: It plays a key role in keeping city streets on the move and is even the object of the best modern designers ' desire .
label: metaphor

text: In Milan , for example , the commission to design the new generation of ‘ Jumbo ’ trams , which went into service in 1979 , was one that leading Italian architects and designers fought over .
label: metaphor

text: After all , the Jumbo , a handsome and imposing articulated unit designed by architect , engineer and critic Klaus Giovanni Koenig , will be seen on the streets of Milan for the next half-century .
label: metaphor

text: Spotlessly clean and popular , the Jumbo is a long-term advertisement for Koenig 's design skills .
label: literal

text: The modern tram is a green machine .
label: literal

text: Assuming the power station at the end of the line burns cleanly , the tram is virtually pollution free .
label: metaphor

text: Standing at traffic lights a Koenig-designed Jumbo is , save for the chatter inside , completely silent .
label: metaphor

text: The overhead wires are so slight that you have to look hard to see them .
label: metaphor

text: Powers of acceleration and braking are remarkable , the latter far greater than any car .
label: metaphor

text: But sadly , there is no indication that the GMA consortium which will design , operate and maintain the first of the new generation British trams in Manchester will share the looks of their Milanese counterparts .
label: metaphor

text: Artists ' impressions show a tram that has more in common with the flat-faced , characterless light trains of the toy-like Docklands Light Railway .
label: metaphor

text: There is still time for GMA ( GEC , Mowlem , Amec and Greater Manchester Buses ) to consider employing an inspired architect or industrial designer .
label: metaphor

text: After all , Mancunians and visitors to the Manchester conurbation are going to have to look at these mechanical millipedes for well into the twenty-first century .
label: metaphor

text: Now that buses are no longer designed to enhance the streets they serve , Manchester has a chance to make a fresh start with its trams .
label: metaphor

text: Manchester is not alone .
label: metaphor

text: Other British towns , Croydon and Southampton among them , are also considering modern tramways .
label: metaphor

text: These are all referred to as ‘ supertram ’ networks , the implication being that the new-generation tram is an altogether more dynamic form of transport than its pre-war predecessors .
label: metaphor

text: What it really means is that the new trams are a hybrid between street car and lightweight suburban train .
label: metaphor

text: Although they will slip through the city centre serving the essential parts — shopping malls , leisure centres , theme parks , amusement arcades and museums — the Manchester supertrams will also head out of town on a mix of reserved track and existing railway lines .
label: metaphor

text: The supertram is , in effect , a low-cost replacement for British Rail 's ageing fleet of suburban diesel multiple-unit trains , those rasping diesels which change gear to the accompaniment of voluminous clouds of acrid black exhaust fumes and the blessing of train spotters .
label: metaphor

text: They will perform some of the same functions , but they will not be an exact replacement for traditional trams .
label: metaphor

text: And although the supertram concept will spread through major cities during the next decade , Blackpool will still be alone in its use of traditional double-deckers .
label: metaphor
