text: Judith Hughes
label: literal

text: SOME OF OUR CHILDREN ARE MISSING
label: literal

text: Children have served philosophy very well .
label: metaphor

text: That is the first thing which anyone surveying the literature would notice .
label: metaphor

text: Along with a selection from a list including women , animals , madmen , foreigners , slaves , patients and imbeciles , children have served in that great class of beings , the ‘ not-men ’ , in contrast with which male philosophers have defined and valued themselves .
label: metaphor

text: Unlike the others who appear and disappear as fashion and progress dictate , children occupy a permanent place in the list partly because of their continuing presence as a potential sub-class , partly because they have never protested and mainly because it is assumed that in favourable circumstances they will become men and therefore require attention .
label: metaphor

text: They have received it in the shape of detailed educational theory carefully worked out to see them through the maturation process from infancy to adulthood .
label: metaphor

text: Generations of philosophers have documented this process .
label: literal

text: Perhaps the best known version is Shakespeare 's seven ages of man which is a poetic statement of what had already been received wisdom for centuries and was to remain so for centuries to come .
label: metaphor

text: Education was to guide the infant through the transition to manhood including such stages as childhood , boyhood and youth .
label: metaphor

text: That is the second thing to notice ; the philosopher 's children are boys .
label: metaphor

text: The fact that at least half of the world 's children would not actually go through this process beyond the first two stages is conveniently forgotten or ignored and , no doubt , the reasons for this were largely social .
label: metaphor

text: But the neglect of girl children through the centuries of theorising is more than a social injustice , though many might think this real and bad enough .
label: literal

text: Education has an end .
label: metaphor

text: Although it is fashionable to talk about its value ‘ for its own sake ’ , what prompts the theorising is the strong and well-founded belief that the experiences of childhood affect the kind of adult which the child turns out to be .
label: metaphor

text: Where the end is person- rather than role-oriented — that is , where the end is the development of the human mind and spirit rather than the production of , say , information technologists — then education is valued in relation to some conception of worthwhile human existence which it is meant to serve .
label: metaphor

text: Such an ideal does not stand isolated from the practices which strive towards it but interacts with those practices , helps to construct them , and is in turn constructed by them .
label: metaphor

text: The great philosophers have always produced such a person-oriented account at least for those whose education was thought to matter .
label: metaphor

text: Education has been directed at the production of the rational , the free , the independent of mind , the dignified , in short , the autonomous human being .
label: metaphor

text: Yet because the philosopher 's adult has traditionally been male , his children boy children , and his educational programmes designed to facilitate the transition between them , the ideal of the fully human person has been masculinised to the point where otherwise thoughtful and sometimes good and wise men have unashamedly admitted that this defining ideal is not applicable to half the species .
label: metaphor

text: Rationality turns into narrow intellectualism , freedom into licence , independence into isolationism , dignity into selfish pride ; the autonomous human being turns out to be no more than a social atom after all .
label: metaphor

text: The degeneration occurs , not because men are congenitally or even incorrigibly narrow , libertine , isolated or selfish , but because in defining themselves as autonomous beings in opposition to other human beings they have had to seek what separates them as a group from others .
label: metaphor

text: It is a curiously paradoxical foundation uponupon which to build a theory of autonomy .
label: metaphor

text: Moral autonomy is concerned with individuals not with groups ; a conception of autonomy which depends upon group membership displays its own contradiction .
label: metaphor

text: This paper is partly about the rejection of certain accounts of autonomy though not with the rejection of the ideal of autonomy itself .
label: metaphor

text: It is also about children .
label: literal

text: WOMEN PHILOSOPHERS AND GIRL CHILDREN
label: literal

text: Why should women in general and women philosophers in particular be specially interested in the nature and status of children ?
label: metaphor

text: There are , of course , the familiar and obvious reasons connected with women 's traditional role in child-rearing but there are less obvious reasons too .
label: metaphor

text: When philosophers dismiss women as ‘ not-men ’ they frequently do more than simply lump them together with children or lunatics .
label: metaphor

text: Explicitly or implicitly the suggestion is that women are children or lunatics or whichever other company they keep .
label: metaphor

text: It would be well to know just what this entails .
label: metaphor

text: Schopenhauer said that women remain big children all their lives ; it would be interesting to know what he thought children were like .
label: metaphor

text: A common result of this is that when the philosophers deny autonomy to women , they do so for the same sorts of reason that they deny it to children and cite lack of rationality , capriciousness and vulnerability among their characteristics .
label: metaphor

text: We can do more than to reject such descriptions of ourselves ; we can ask further questions : are children like this ? is this why children are not autonomous ?
label: metaphor

text: Again , women well know what it is like to be treated as children and they find it offensive .
label: metaphor

text: It would therefore be reasonable to consider whether children find it offensive to be treated like children .
label: metaphor

text: Is being treated as a child an intrinsically humiliating and self-denying experience ?
label: literal

text: What is it to be treated as a child ?
label: literal

text: Women philosophers are in a special position to consider such questions for in the image of the philosopher 's child they see themselves .
label: metaphor

text: It is no accident that the liberation of women , such as it is , should form part of a wider movement of liberation in general ; liberation for one part of the ‘ not-men ’ is bound to have a knock-on effect when your fellow groups are sometimes quite literally identified with you .
label: metaphor

text: The assumption that all groups in the ‘ not-men ’ class are identical with each other is so firmly rooted that , as we shall see in the fourth section , it is readily assumed even by modern libertarian thinkers that showing that , for example , some ground for distinguishing between men and women is false or irrelevant , immediately commits us to the view that the same ground is irrelevant in distinguishing men from children .
label: metaphor

text: ‘ That 's what they used to say about women ’ is not a proof that saying it about a child is false .
label: metaphor

text: But it should make us very suspicious .
label: metaphor

text: That when women are given the vote it follows that children should be given it too is no argument at all , but a version of it occurs in modern debates over the justice or injustice of Mill 's famous disclaimer in his essay On Liberty .
label: metaphor

text: Having denied that we may ever legitimately interfere with the liberty of another except on the grounds of self-protection , Mill ( 1910 ) asserts :
label: metaphor

text: this principle is meant to apply only to human beings in the maturity of their faculties .
label: metaphor

text: We are not speaking of children or of young persons below the age which the law may fix as that of manhood or womanhood .
label: metaphor

text: Those who are still in a state to require being taken care of by others must be protected against their own actions as well as against external injury .
label: metaphor

text: This view , as we shall see , has been attacked on the grounds that it rests on the false assumption that the distinction between adults and children is identical with the distinction between rational and non-rational beings .
label: metaphor

text: The attacks are based on empirical observation ; most women and older children are actually quite as rational as most men while some men are actually less rational .
label: metaphor

text: If we agree that in that case women should be embraced by the liberty principle then so should children .
label: metaphor

text: I shall suggest that this does not follow because rationality is not in fact the grounds for the distinction in the first place .
label: metaphor

text: Partly to redress the balance and partly because talking about ‘ children ’ covers such a wide range of potential images , I shall try to keep before my mind an ordinary 10-year-old of our society .
label: metaphor

text: She is the child of this paper unless I indicate otherwise .
label: metaphor

text: Throughout we should ask ourselves , does this ( whatever is being said ) apply to her ?
label: metaphor

text: First of all , let us remind ourselves of the traditional picture of children drawn for us by some great philosophers of the past .
label: metaphor

text: One thing they are all quite sure about is that children are not like adults ; in particular they agree that children lack some capacity for rational thought which adults have .
label: metaphor

text: the slave has absolutely no deliberative faculty ; the woman has but its authority is imperfect ; so has the child , but in this case it is immature .
label: metaphor

text: ( Aristotle , 1959,1260A )
label: literal

text: Children … are not endued with Reason at all , till they have attained the use of speech but are called Reasonable Creatures for the possibility apparent of having the use of Reason in time to come .
label: metaphor

text: Children … love to be treated as Rational Creatures sooner than is imagined … by which …
label: literal

text: I mean , that you should make them sensible by the Mildness of your carriage , and the composure even in your correction of them , that what you do is reasonable in you and useful and necessary for them .
label: metaphor

text: In training for youth , the child must be given reasons ; in the training of the infant for childhood this can not be done .
label: metaphor

text: Young children ought merely to have things shown to them as they are , or they get puzzled and ask question after question .
label: metaphor

text: But as we approach the age of youth reason appears .
label: metaphor

text: At what age ought the education for youth to begin ?
label: metaphor

text: Roughly at the age of ten years , when by nature the child enters the stage of youth and begins to reflect …
label: metaphor

text: The youth … is capable of having principles ; his religious and moral ideas can be cultivated , and he is able to attend to his own refinement .
label: metaphor

text: If a society lets any considerable number of its members grow up mere children , incapable of being acted on by rational consideration of distant motives , society has itself to blame for the consequences .
label: metaphor

text: What are the philosophers ' children like ?
label: literal

text: They have an ‘ immature ’ deliberative faculty ( Aristotle ) , are not ‘ endued with Reason ’ ( Hobbes ) , until roughly the age of 10 ( Kant ) and are ‘ incapable of being acted upon by rational consideration of distant motives ’ ( Mill ) .
label: metaphor

text: But they are not completely lost causes .
label: metaphor

text: The immature deliberative faculty will mature ; children have the ‘ possibility apparent ’ of turning into rational beings ( Hobbes ) ; they love to be reated as though they were rational though they are not so yet ( Locke ) ; you can give the prerational child reasons for acting in certain ways and he will turn into the youth who is capable of having principles ( Kant ) .
label: metaphor

text: Until the time when these things happen then Mill 's disclaimer comes into operation .
label: metaphor

text: Children must be taken care of by others and protected from external injury and against their own actions .
label: metaphor

text: The traditional view is encapsulated in the claim that children are not autonomous ; that is , on a standard interpretation , they lack the capacity to act rationally in pursuit of their own self-chosen goals .
label: metaphor

text: It is then a matter of preference whether you say that they can not choose the goals or that they can not form strategies to achieve them or both .
label: metaphor

text: In either case , the political implication is that denying rights to children is entirely justified , and there the matter rests .
label: metaphor

text: In all this , there are perhaps a couple of things which look plausible when we compare the philosopher 's child with our mental picture ; Aristotle 's observation that children are immature and Mill 's suggestion that they might need protection .
label: metaphor

text: Beyond that , the similarities seem remote .
label: metaphor

text: There is obviously something wrong with a portrayal of children as totally lacking in reason until they leap out of bed on their tenth birthday announcing that they are now able to act on principle .
label: literal

text: Apart from being false , such an account leaves no room in our thinking about children for things like teaching and learning , or development in understanding and character and all those other concepts which refer to processes and not to states .
label: metaphor

text: The tension between these theoretical views of children as non-rational , non-autonomous beings and the practical knowledge of real children is evident in those quotations from Hobbes and Locke and Kant and Mill .
label: metaphor

text: Children , according to Hobbes , have the ‘ possibility apparent ’ of becoming reasonable .
label: literal

text: In what does the possibility consist ?
label: literal

text: Hobbes is not using an inductive argument here ; the ‘ possibility apparent ’ is not an inductive argument from observations about past children but is meant to refer to some discernible feature of present ones .
label: metaphor

text: Hobbes does not tell us , but whatever it is it had better be something which a monkey does not have .
label: metaphor

text: It is not language since Hobbes is here talking about the prelinguistic child .
label: metaphor

text: Perhaps it consists in the ability to respond intelligently to the language of others .
label: metaphor

text: But then , either Hobbes has failed to distinguish the child from at least the higher and domesticated animals or the force of ‘ intelligently ’ must be explained in such a way as to exclude animals .
label: metaphor

text: In any case , if such a qualification is called for it is hard to see how a creature with no rationality at all could possess it .
label: metaphor

text: Locke 's remarks are just as puzzling .
label: literal

text: Children are definitely not rational but love to be treated as if they were .
label: literal

text: How is this possible ?
label: literal

text: Apparently they like having things explained to them without understanding either the explanation or even what an explanation is .
label: metaphor

text: Perhaps he just means that they like the sound of my voice ?
label: literal

text: Well , maybe they do , but making any old noises is clearly not sufficient to enter the rationality stakes ; I must at least say something .
label: metaphor

text: Is it just that I talk to them that they love ?
label: literal

text: Maybe , but I can also , if I like , talk to my car , but yelling at it in the approved Basil Fawlty manner is hardly treating it as rational .
label: literal

text: Lockean children have the added amazing ability to recognise reason in you without possessing any themselves , while Kantian kids , two stages back from rationality , have the disconcerting habit of getting puzzled and asking questions .
label: metaphor

text: Mill 's minors are a little more complicated .
label: literal

text: Part of the time he sees them in the familiar way as creatures who lack rationality to at least some degree .
label: metaphor

text: But in the disclaimer his children need above all to be protected from the ghastly consequences of their own actions .
label: literal

text: Their problem seems to be not one of the inability to choose goals or to form strategies for achieving them , but an incorrigible propensity to choose the wrong ones and an awesome efficiency in achieving them unless adults intervene .
label: metaphor

text: All in all , it is a pretty unconvincing picture .
label: metaphor

text: If you say that children are completely non-rational then you have to account for the fact that they become rational , and to do that it appears from these examples that you have to assume that they already are .
label: metaphor

text: If , on the other hand , you allow rationality to children , then you can not use their lack of it as a criterion to distinguish them from adults .
label: metaphor

text: Hobbes et al .
label: literal

text: are not aware of the unreality of their original pictures which is why , often in the same sentence , they produce these contradictions .
label: metaphor

text: The one thing they do not do is to re-examine the original for the tell-tale signs of forgery .
label: metaphor

text: ILLEGITIMATE INFERENCES
label: literal

text: The recognition that children can not simply be written off in the rationality stakes and can not therefore be denied autonomy on this account has led some writers to conclude that they can not , therefore , be denied it on any account .
label: metaphor

text: We should notice that this view is not just a flight of fancy from the loony left , the pederast lobby or children themselves .
label: metaphor

text: It is also to be found in stronger or weaker versions of more cautious academic thought .
label: metaphor

text: In Escape from Childhood ( 1974 ) , John Holt notes that children are , in fact , capable of a great deal more than modern society allows them to be .
label: metaphor

text: He sees childhood as a fairly modern invention designed to fit adult rather than children 's needs , and an oppressive invention at that .
label: metaphor

text: He suggests that children should be given a comprehensive range of civil and legal rights including the right to vote , to manage their own financial affairs , to direct and manage their own education and to control their own sex lives and
label: metaphor

text: to make and enter into , on a basis of mutual consent , quasifamilial relationships outside one 's immediate family — i.e. the right to seek and choose guardians other than one 's own parents and to be legally dependent on them .
label: metaphor

text: This is also the view put forward by John Harris , though in less specific terms .
label: metaphor

text: Like Holt , Harris believes that the so-called incompetence of children is an adult invention imposed on children for adults ' convenience .
label: metaphor

text: He makes a firm proposal that the age of majority should be gradually reduced to 10 years , and remarks :
label: metaphor

text: We must remember that to deny someone control of their own lives is to offer them a most profound insult , not to mention the which the frustration of their wishes and the setting at naught of their own plans for themselves will add .
label: metaphor

text: Perhaps we should conduct annual examinations from an early age to be sure that we do as little of this sort of damage as possible ?
label: metaphor

text: Now Holt and Harris both have many wise , enlightened and humane observations to make about some of the injustices which we inflict upon children , but as these remarks show , putting them right without inflicting equally grave injustice is no easy matter .
label: metaphor

text: Both of them appear to suffer from a form of mental myopia in imagining the consequences of such proposals , and I am not here referring only to Mill-type consequences of harm brought about by unwise decisions .
label: metaphor

text: What , we may ask Holt , happens to the child who , dissatisfied at home , seeks in vain for guardians who would suit him ?
label: metaphor

text: What if no one wants him ?
label: literal

text: Our papers are currently full of ‘ hard-to-place ’ children in local authority care advertising for foster or adoptive parents .
label: metaphor

text: In such a situation the skilled care of social workers is crucial to ensuring that an unwanted by-product of success for some children is not the total destruction of self-esteem for others .
label: metaphor

text: What , we may ask Harris , happens to the child who repeatedly fails his annual examination ?
label: literal

text: To impose such a test on children would be a particularly invidious way of discriminating against them , unless Harris has in mind that we should all undergo such examination .
label: metaphor

text: He might then be open to bitter objections from many adults .
label: metaphor

text: These two suggestions , far from being enlightened liberation of all children , are actually oppression of a deeply damaging kind to at least some , and Harris 's suggestion contains a capacity criterion in disguise .
label: metaphor

text: In any case , it would be dishonest to pretend that Mill-type consequences are not relevant here .
label: literal

text: Suppose Holt 's 6-year-old does opt out of school ?
label: literal

text: What happens to her then ?
label: literal

text: What happens if her father is unwilling or unable to stay at home with her ?
label: literal

text: Is it any better to oblige her to go abseiling or butterfly-catching instead ?
label: literal

text: However much she may enjoy such pursuits , there will be times when she would actually rather wander the streets unaccompanied .
label: literal

text: Given that Holt is presumably not volunteering himself to take care of her , who will ?
label: metaphor

text: His view that letting children run in and out of busy airports smartly avoiding the traffic is perfectly reasonable depends upon a conception of a child which is far narrower than even the sex divide .
label: metaphor

text: Holt 's child is actually the Artful Dodger ; mercifully , not all children are .
label: metaphor

text: There are other difficulties too .
label: literal

text: It is not clear whether or not Harris thinks that children of 10 should be obliged to take on full political status whether or not they want to , but Holt clearly does not .
label: metaphor

text: He proposes that ‘ the rights , privileges , duties , responsibilities of adult citizens be made available to any young person , of whatever age , who wants to make use of them ’ ( Holt , 1974 , p. 15 ) .
label: metaphor

text: If Holt thinks that this proposal would remove an arbitrary boundary line between adults and children , then he is mistaken .
label: metaphor

text: The point about an adult citizen is that he has these rights , privileges , duties and responsibilities whether or not he wants them .
label: metaphor

text: He may not exercise his rights or he may shirk his duties , but he can not forgo them .
label: metaphor

text: They are not just available to him , they are his .
label: literal

text: That is what being a citizen involves .
label: metaphor

text: Rights and privileges do not pose any particular problems in the case of children .
label: literal

text: Holt can and does believe that children should have them as adults do , and then leaves it up to the child to decide whether or not to exercise them .
label: metaphor

text: But the same can not be said for duties and responsibilities .
label: metaphor

text: Failure to exercise one 's rights may be morally neutral ; failure to carry out one 's duties is not .
label: metaphor

text: It would be perfectly possible to give the rights to children without imposing the duties on them , the one does not entail the other , but we would then still be distinguishing between adults and children as citizens .
label: metaphor

text: Children still would not have full political status .
label: metaphor

text: Duties and responsibilities are not merely available to a citizen ; they are an integral part of being a citizen .
label: metaphor

text: Holt does not want children to be obliged to take on any of these responsibilities and he manages to make his point by concentrating solely on the rights so that he can remark :
label: metaphor

text: I do not say , either , that these rights and duties should be tied into one package , that if a young person wants to assume any of them , he must assume them all .
label: metaphor

text: He should be able to pick and choose .
label: metaphor

text: If he can ‘ pick and choose ’ , I suggest , he is not a citizen , he does not have full political status and he is quite distinguishable on these grounds alone from the adults around him who do not have this option .
label: metaphor

text: Holt and Harris both , in the end , face the same problem .
label: metaphor

text: They attack the status quo by pointing out that the reasons given for denying rights to children are bad reasons , and then explicitly or implicitly deny them duties for no reason at all .
label: metaphor

text: Whatever else such a strategy may achieve , it certainly does not manage to produce a situation in which children are politically indistinguishable from adults and it rests on premises which , unless they can be defended , gain nothing for any defence to the charge of arbitrariness .
label: metaphor

text: WHEN IN DOUBT , GO BACK TO ARISTOTLE
label: metaphor

text: The trouble with all the views which we have looked at is that they tie the notion of autonomy firmly and solely to that of knowledge interpreted in either a broad or narrow sense .
label: metaphor

text: That it is firmly tied must be correct ; the inhabitants of Brave New World are not autonomous precisely because they are denied access to relevant information .
label: metaphor

text: Relevant knowledge is a precondition of autonomy but it is not synonymous with it .
label: metaphor

text: Aristotle said something very interesting in that extract from the Politics which I quoted earlier ; he said that women have a deliberative faculty but that it lacks full authority .
label: metaphor

text: What did he mean ?
label: literal
